summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend are in a public row that began when Merson criticized Townsend's selection for the England squad. Townsend responded by scoring an equalizer against Italy and taunting Merson on Twitter. Merson then admitted he was wrong and praised the goal. However, Merson later restarted the disagreement after Townsend was brought on as a substitute for Tottenham with only seven minutes remaining in a 0-0 draw against Burnley, tweeting at him: "Just been watching the game, did you miss the coach? #RubberDub #7minutes."

According to FC Tokyo's president Naoki Ogane, Chelsea has made a formal offer for their 22-year-old forward, Yoshinori Muto. If the deal is completed, the Japan international would be loaned to Vitesse Arnhem for the next season. Ogane claims the offer is not connected to Chelsea's sponsorship deal with the Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who would be the first Japanese player at Chelsea, called the offer an "honour" but stated that he has not yet decided whether to accept it. A £4 million deal has been mooted for the player.

A large-scale Finnish study of over 12,000 children found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. Repeated prescriptions before the age of two also increased the odds of being a fat toddler, with boys being particularly prone to weight gain. While the study did not prove causation, researchers suggest that antibiotics may kill gut bugs that would normally consume some food, freeing up more for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The lead author, Dr. Antti Saari, warned that this effect may contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic and highlighted the importance of the "judicious use of antibiotics in infancy."

During the Changing of the Guard ceremony at Buckingham Palace, a guard slipped on a manhole cover and fell in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident was filmed by a tourist named David Meadwell. The guard dropped his rifle and knocked his bearskin hat, but quickly got to his feet, appearing embarrassed. It is thought that metal protectors on the soles of his boots caused the slip. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E networks are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which will air in 2016 and be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History. The series is about Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in America. LeVar Burton, who starred in the original, will co-executive produce the new version. The remake is described as "original" and "contemporary," will draw more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family," and will consult with scholars for authenticity. The goal is to bring the story to a new generation of viewers.

Police are investigating claims from a former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, that palace aides tried to force him into an orgy at Clarence House in January 1978. Mr. Lawler, who was 27 at the time, states that on his first day of work, he was pinned to a chair and groped, causing him to leave the job the same day. He contacted palace officials again last year, but he claims his complaints were ignored for months before the police were notified. A retired royal aide was interviewed but denied involvement. The Royal Household has now stated it will cooperate with the police probe, which is ongoing.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a rap video parody of the theme from "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." The video, which has over 1.7 million views on YouTube, was made for loved ones living far away and took five takes to film. In the clip, the couple raps about their life, family questions about parenthood, and how it took two months to conceive. The video ends with them sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. The couple was surprised by the video's success.

A gray jacket and skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* was sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills. The dress, which has faded from its original slate blue-gray color, was part of a collection from James Tumblin, who had purchased it for $20 in the 1960s when it was about to be thrown away. Other items sold at the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000), and a black bonnet ($30,000). The passage also notes that Hattie McDaniel won an Academy Award for her role in the film, becoming the first African-American actor to do so.

A two-year-old boy fell 10 to 12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his mother dangled him over the railing. The boy's parents rescued him from the pit. He was taken to the hospital in stable condition with minor bumps and bruises and was not attacked by the cheetahs. According to the text, the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been turned to point directly at a house's front door. This camera has not been working for over two years, as it was one of around 300 fixed cameras in the West Midlands that were switched off in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. It is a mystery who re-pointed the camera. A spokesman for Birmingham City Council confirmed they are aware of the situation, will send an engineer to the site, and may remove the camera completely. The council is developing a pilot for new digital cameras, but this specific camera on Wellington Road is not part of the plan.

Usain Bolt will compete as part of the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, an announcement made by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt has confirmed he is "fit, healthy and ready to run." JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressed that he was "extremely pleased" with Bolt's availability. The full team list for the competition will be announced shortly.

Barcelona teammates Neymar and Dani Alves, along with Neymar's sister Rafaella, attended a Euro League basketball El Clasico, where Barcelona's team defeated Real Madrid 85-80. Despite the loss, Real Madrid remains ahead of Barcelona in their division. In football, Neymar recently captained Brazil to a 1-0 win against Chile. Before the international break, Barcelona's football team had won their own El Clasico, moving four points clear at the top of La Liga. They are scheduled to play Celta Vigo next as they compete for a treble.

From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard. Save the Children fears 400 migrants could be missing from a ship that survivors said capsized, but the Italian coast guard has not been able to confirm the incident. According to the International Organization for Migration (IOM), Italy registered over 10,000 migrants in the first three months of 2015, with at least 480 dying while crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. Deaths are often attributed to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by smugglers.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger does not know the exact reason why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool but is happy with the decision. Sanchez, who was courted by multiple clubs after Barcelona decided to sell him, has made an instant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals. Wenger was aware of Liverpool's interest and thought it could have been leverage in the negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Wenger has also played down speculation linking Arsenal with a move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and praised Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for how he has developed his team.

On June 7, at London's Olympic Velodrome, Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record. A four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, Wiggins will try to beat the current record of 52.491km, which was set by Australian rider Rohan Dennis. Wiggins recently finished his career with Team Sky and will ride for his own team in the Tour de Yorkshire before the record attempt. Tickets for the event go on sale on April 19, and it will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams defeated Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in a Fed Cup play-off, a match she described as an "eye-opener." Williams said the struggle made her realize she is not as ready for the claycourt season as she thought and that she needs to change her mindset from playing as if she were on a hard court. Despite her singles win, the US team was beaten 3-2 by Italy after Williams and Alison Riske lost their doubles match 6-0 6-3. As a result, the US was relegated to World Group II. Tough weather conditions made serving difficult for the players.

River Plate is keen to sign their former striker, Radamel Falcao, who is currently on loan at Manchester United. The club's vice president, Matias Patanian, stated, "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open," but admitted that a deal is complicated. Falcao has struggled at Manchester United, scoring just four Premier League goals, and it is uncertain whether the club will exercise the option to keep him or if he will return to his parent club, Monaco. Falcao previously spent eight years with River Plate, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances for the first team before leaving for Porto in 2009. He has recently been in good form for his country, Colombia, scoring three goals in two games to equal their all-time goalscoring record.

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson has become the official face of the dry shampoo brand Batiste for its 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This is the 19-year-old's first brand collaboration. The international campaign, which was put together by the MILES agency, includes campaign images and a TV advertisement featuring Henderson's single, "Mirror Man." Henderson has expressed her excitement, stating she regularly uses the product.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association to thank the community for its support, has been erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin. This has caused shock and been called "disrespectful" by the family and friends of Aaron Siler, a 26-year-old man who was shot and killed by Torres the previous month. Siler, who was wanted on a felony warrant, was shot on March 14 following a pursuit after he "armed himself with a weapon." Officer Torres is on leave while the shooting is under investigation. Ten days before shooting Siler, Torres also shot and wounded another man, Terry Knight, in an incident that was later deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan in the town of Negur. Three of the militants were also killed. According to an Iranian official, the militants crossed into Iran from Pakistan. A militant group called Jaish al Adal, described as an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group, claimed responsibility for the attack. This group has also claimed responsibility for past attacks, including one in October 2013 that killed 14 Iranian border guards. Iranian officials have asked Pakistan to catch the surviving assailants. The Pakistani government condemned the attack, is investigating, and has asked Iran to share any evidence.

In response to a question from lawmaker and former wrestler Antonio Inoki, Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) had never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. Nakatani explained that when the ASDF scrambles jets for unidentified objects, they have found birds or other flying objects, but never anything believed to have come from anywhere other than Earth. The exchange was not the first time Japanese politicians have discussed visitors from another planet; in 2007, a previous Defense Minister considered the legal ramifications of defending against an invasion from outer space.

A 35-year-old passenger named Jin Pai was hospitalized with deep cuts to his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport broke and smashed. He was standing on the rim because he was "worried it might not be clean." After being found bleeding on the floor, he was taken to a hospital where he received dozens of stitches. The passenger confessed to his friends that he was squatting but later told police he was sitting when the toilet gave way, possibly to avoid paying compensation. Authorities believe the incident was an accident.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of images for his book, which roughly translates to "Daughter and Salary Man." The photos feature fathers dressed in sharp suits leaping into the air next to their po-faced daughters, who are in casual clothing. The images, taken in front of various Japanese landmarks, are intended to allow the fathers to express their fun side. While very little is known about the pictures, they are generating interest online for their curious nature.

Following the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director, focus has shifted to Kevin Pietersen, who was present at a Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval. Downton's sacking has paved the way for a potential return to the England team for the 34-year-old, who was axed by Downton in 2014 after a disastrous Ashes tour. In an effort to rejoin the Test set-up, Pietersen has rejoined Surrey for the county championship season. During the photo shoot, he displayed a range of emotions, appearing both in deep thought and in a jovial mood. Surrey is set to play Oxford MCCU on Sunday and will begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19.

Brazilian coach Ze Maria was sacked by the Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt for the second time in one week. He was first fired on Wednesday and reinstated the next day, but was dismissed again after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday. The defeat left Ceahlaul in 16th place, six points from safety. Ze Maria, the club's third coach of the season, will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

According to his former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao must be regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United. Falcao struggled at United after a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals all season. As a result, it is unlikely that United will pay the £46 million to make his transfer permanent. Dirar believes Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played in the Champions League, even though he also revealed that Falcao was not happy in France.

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a "very tall" man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a "distinctive" cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. On Saturday at approximately 12:30 pm, the man demanded cash from the owner's daughter, threw the cash register to the ground, and fled with the till drawer and up to $1,500. No weapons were used, and the robber is still at large. Police are asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.

A video of a large crocodile swimming in a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times online. The dog, which was black with a red collar, belonged to a local bike shop owner and had approached the water's edge. According to a witness, New Zealander Tim Weston, the crocodile came from a sanctuary 200 meters away and held the dog in its mouth for hours. Crocodiles are a common sight in Puerto Vallarta as the resort is built amongst mangroves, and they are also spotted on the resort's golf course.

Following a 2-0 defeat to Southampton, Hull City manager Steve Bruce is adamant he can keep the team in the Premier League and avoid relegation. The loss, which came from a James Ward-Prowse penalty and a Graziano Pelle strike, leaves Hull two points above the drop zone with six games remaining. These fixtures include difficult matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes the team's struggles to long-term injuries to key players but is convinced they can get the results needed to stay up.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after allowing pupils to change their SATs exam answers after the test had finished. Guffick also altered some answers himself. Following an investigation, the Department for Education annulled the entire school's SATs results for that year. Guffick admitted the allegations amounted to unacceptable professional conduct but claimed he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible. A conduct panel found his actions dishonest, and he was given 28 days to appeal the decision.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard is married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri. The couple, who have a son together, have been dating since 2012 and married last year in a beach wedding in Mauritius. Lindegaard has struggled for playing time since joining the club in 2010, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons, and is now the third-choice goalkeeper. Beqiri, who is Swedish with Albanian roots, has over 17,000 followers on Instagram, where she regularly posts modelling pictures.

A set of 13 glowing blue letters from Yankee Stadium, owned by Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction. The letters were expected to bring in $300,000 to $600,000 but received no bids. The only person to raise a paddle was a Sotheby's employee with a $260,000 bid intended to start the auction. Jackson purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium's final game in 2008. The letters were installed in 1976. At the same auction, a New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded players Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe of their professional responsibilities after Sterling was exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide and pictures emerged of both players with shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to the players but confirmed they will not be disciplined. The incidents occurred before Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, for which Sterling is set to play. Captain Steven Gerrard is available for the match after a suspension, but Rodgers has not confirmed if he will be recalled.

After playing for Germany in their 2-0 win against Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier, Arsenal's Mesut Ozil posted a picture on Twitter of himself relaxing at home with his dog. He is now preparing for a Premier League match against Liverpool. Ozil missed Arsenal's previous game against Newcastle due to illness, but has been in fine form since returning from injury in January, with three goals and four assists. He stated that he is adjusting to English football and fits in "perfectly."

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, with whom they are "very happy." Enrique, who took charge last summer and has a contract until 2016, has impressed during his tenure. The team is six games away from winning the La Liga title and is still capable of winning three trophies. In a recent match, Barcelona defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Liverpool's vice-captain, Jordan Henderson, has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club that will run until 2020 and is worth around £100,000 per week. Henderson, who was signed from Sunderland in June 2011 for £16 million, has scored seven goals and provided 13 assists this season. He is the third player to agree to a contract extension, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, and is being considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard departs. Talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis has stated he wants to stay at Chelsea until his three-year contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him. Luis, who has struggled to make the left back position his own, says he is happy at Chelsea. He also noted that manager Jose Mourinho is demanding focus from the team for the nine difficult games remaining in the Premier League title run-in. Luis recently played for Brazil in friendly wins against France and Chile.

Following an outcry on his behalf, Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban overturned on appeal. Hughes was initially suspended and shown a red card after a disciplinary panel ruled he had been ‘reckless’ when his knee accidentally collided with George North's head as North scored a try on March 27. The incident left North unconscious for the third time in two months, and he was subsequently advised to take a minimum of one month off. The initial ban was heavily criticised, with many, including players Austin Healey and Joe Marler, calling it a "joke." After an appeal by his club, Wasps, the ban and red card were rescinded. The appeal panel, which had evidence not available to the original panel, concluded that the incident was accidental and no act of foul play occurred. Hughes missed one match while awaiting the appeal and is now free to return to action.

Fiery, deep reddish sunsets in Washington were caused by smoke from raging wildfires in Siberia. The fires, which started from farmers burning grass, spread due to strong winds and destroyed dozens of villages. Atmospheric winds carried the smoke across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest. The red color of the sunset is a result of smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange to penetrate the air. The sunsets will lose their reddish hue as the smoke dissipates.

Becky Schoenig's new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway in St. Louis, Missouri. On April 1, police found and returned the car after a man named Mick Sexton recognized it and provided a tip. The car had been modified with spray-painted red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Schoenig reacted with humor on Facebook, thanking the thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle. The car required professional cleaning due to a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. To honor the man who found her car, Schoenig is creating a smoothie called "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot.

Manchester City players will lose bonuses of £500,000 per man if they fail to qualify for the Champions League. The total amount at stake for the squad is around £12 million. These incentivised contracts are in place to keep the club within financial fair play rules. After losing to Manchester United, City is in fourth place, with their European qualification "in the balance." The top three Premier League teams qualify automatically, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini stated that the team has let its season "disintegrate" and thrown the last three months "into the garbage." This poor form may also cause them to face a battle to sign world-class players like Paul Pogba.

In a 'mini-derby' match, Manchester United's Under 18s beat Manchester City's 1-0. The winning goal was a free-kick scored by Callum Gribbin, who had also drawn the foul. The match was played at Moss Lane, Altrincham's home ground, with free entry for the close to 1,000 spectators. Of the 22 players who started the game, 13 were English, and 10 of those were Mancunian. The result leaves United two points behind the leaders, Middlesbrough, in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series, while City have now lost both of their matches in the series.

Following a 1-1 draw with Italy, England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon. Hart, who earned his 50th cap, called Buffon a "legend of the game" and an "inspiration" after the Italian veteran claimed his 147th cap. Hart stated that he looks up to the 37-year-old Buffon and is still learning from him. While proud of his 50 caps, Hart expressed his desire to keep playing for his country and earn more.

Mexican restaurant Chipotle is partnering with the Postmates app to offer food delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities, entering the $70 billion food delivery market. A nine percent service charge will be added to these orders, and Postmates' delivery fees start at $5, varying by distance and demand. Other chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also entering the delivery market. Two presidential candidates, Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton, were recently seen in Chipotle restaurants.

In a front-page opinion piece in The Boston Globe, Bill and Denise Richard, the parents of 8-year-old Martin, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have made a plea to take the death penalty off the table for the convicted bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. They stated they would support the Department of Justice in this decision in exchange for the defendant spending the rest of his life in prison without any possibility of release and waiving all rights to appeal. The Richards, whose daughter Jane was also severely injured, wrote that the continued pursuit of the death penalty could bring years of appeals, prolonging their anguish and preventing their family from moving forward. They specified that they were only speaking for themselves.

A Boeing 747 jumbo jet has been converted into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire at a cost of £400 million over a three-year period. The plane, which would normally carry 600 passengers, was built for a single tycoon but can host dozens of guests. It includes bedrooms, multiple lounges, a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a conference room, a 'state room', and an 'aeroloft' on the top deck with eight beds for guests.

On Tuesday, SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying a Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station. A secondary attempt to land the rocket on a floating barge was unsuccessful; the rocket landed but tipped over because it came in "too hard for survival." SpaceX founder Elon Musk's goal in landing rockets is to reuse them to reduce the cost of space access. The Dragon spacecraft is delivering over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including an espresso maker, to the space station. After about five weeks, it will be loaded with over 3,000 pounds of science experiments and trash to return to Earth. This was the sixth SpaceX mission to the station, and the launch was the second attempt for this mission after the first was scrubbed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel, located inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas. The first couple will be chosen through a contest in collaboration with NBC's *Today* show, with the wedding scheduled for Thursday, April 23. The prize for the winning couple includes a free wedding reception, a hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla Presley, who was involved in the chapel's design, has made it clear that there will be no Elvis impersonators, stating, "This is all first-class... This is not a joke."

Following a 2-0 victory over Newcastle United, Liverpool's vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League. The win, secured with goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen, places Liverpool four points behind Manchester City. The match was the 47th of the season for both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet. The victory was seen as important after recent disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal.

In a key Serie A match for Champions League places, Roma ended a four-month home winless streak by defeating Napoli. Miralem Pjanic scored the winning goal in the 25th minute from a counter-attack. Roma's goalkeeper, Morgan de Sanctis, made numerous saves in the second half to secure the victory. The win moved second-place Roma four points ahead of Lazio, while Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, leaving them in fifth place. Security for the match was tight, with 1,000 police officers deployed and residents from the Naples region barred from buying tickets, but no problems were reported.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played a 0-0 goalless draw in a League One match at the Keepmoat Stadium. Due to the uneventful game, Doncaster's media team created a 27-second highlights video for the club's YouTube channel. The video contained only 14 seconds of match action, showing the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

A man named Roland Giroux has a remarkable relationship with his pet blood parrot cichlid. He puts his hand in the fish tank to stroke and massage the fish, which relaxes and stays still for the interaction. The fish will swim away but repeatedly returns to the man's hand to be stroked again. Giroux developed this bond after removing two other fish that were bullying the cichlid and began hand-feeding it frozen blood worms. He now plays with the fish for at least 15 minutes each day. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes is known as a fiery character in the England cricket team. An incident where he broke his wrist punching a locker serves as a reminder for him to channel his aggression correctly. After a recent clash with Marlon Samuels, England coach Peter Moores spoke with him, and Stokes's response was considered "spot on." The author believes Stokes needs careful man-management to ensure his aggression is controlled and results in runs and wickets. While his place in the team can be questioned, England wants to play him as much as possible to help him grow and reach his full potential.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium is a 33,000 sell-out. Wales and Belgium are the top two teams in Group B, both with 11 points from five games, though Belgium leads on goal difference. This is Wales' best opportunity to qualify for a major tournament since 1958. The sell-out was caused by overwhelming demand following Wales' 3-0 victory over Israel. While there was speculation the match could be moved to the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules prevented the venue from being changed. The Wales squad prefers playing at the Cardiff City Stadium.

England coach John Peacock has announced his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. As the defending champions with a 100% qualifying record, the team is in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7, followed by games against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. Notable squad inclusions are Chelsea's Jay Dasilva, first-time call-ups for Arsenal's Stephy Mavididi and Chris Willock, and a recall for Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold.

Manchester City are keen to sign 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is also of interest to Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously rejected a move to Barcelona's academy at age 12 to continue his studies. Manchester City have held discussions with Anderlecht's chairman, Roger Vanden Stock, to agree on a compensation package.

A 33-year-old Mexican national and transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. The cause of death was injuries to the head and neck. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and told to return for further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward.

A woman named Dawn, who has had seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to accuse her housemate and friend, Jamie, of stealing £207. The money had been set aside for a £500 gravestone for her baby, Daniel James. A lie detector test revealed that Jamie, a convicted burglar, had taken the money. It was also revealed that Jamie had sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing to the theft but blaming his girlfriend, Carol. Upon learning the truth, Dawn burst into tears, stormed off the stage, and later said she felt "betrayed" and "horrible."

On Wednesday, ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis in northern Iraq, most of whom were women, children, the ill, or elderly. Officials gave conflicting counts of 217 and 228 released individuals. The reason for the release was not immediately clear, though a Peshmerga commander stated that Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate it. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil. This event follows ISIS's takeover of Yazidi towns the previous summer, which resulted in killings, captures, a major humanitarian crisis, and an international response that included airstrikes. The Yazidis are described as a minority group of Kurdish descent.

Tottenham and England striker Harry Kane is the subject of a new animation by Copa90 which features some of his best goals and celebrations from the season. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was created using still photographs and has been released ahead of the PFA awards ceremony. Kane is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards, competing against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is the right person to continue managing Liverpool, despite a third season without a trophy and an expected finish outside the top four. Carragher suggests that new players have not yet settled in and that Rodgers, the players, and staff should look to next season to win a trophy and get back into the top four, noting that the right signings will be critical. The passage also states that Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in schools in deprived areas.

At East Midlands Airport, a four-year-old boy named James Hayward had his plastic toy nerf gun confiscated from his hand luggage by security, who also performed a "thorough patting down" of the child. The boy's father, Phil Hayward, described the security checks as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous." East Midlands Airport defended the decision, stating that government regulations prohibit any items that resemble a prohibited item, such as "replica or model guns." The airport offered to post the toy back to the family, and a replacement was purchased for the boy after their holiday in Lanzarote.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a "girlfriend/wife." His requirements for a partner include loving pets, being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, a good cook, and enjoying the outdoors. In his ad, Rich described himself as 175cm tall, with an athletic build, heavily tattooed, successful, a property owner, and someone who does not drink, smoke, or do drugs. The position may offer accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, and a free gym membership. The ad also stated that former partners need not apply. Daily Mail Australia was unsuccessful in its attempt to contact him.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is proposing to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to twelve and to change the definition of "home-grown" to training in England for three years before the age of 18, rather than 21. While the Premier League opposes these changes, Dyke has received the backing of five former England managers: Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren. In a signed letter, they argue that the proposals are necessary because the pool of English talent at the top level is shrinking, which is a disadvantage for any England manager and risks England falling further behind other leading football nations.

In an upcoming episode of Poldark, Demelza gives birth to a daughter with Ross Poldark. Ross gazes lovingly at the baby and tells Demelza she makes him a better man. The passage notes that the pregnancy's timeline is unconvincing, jumping from the announcement in the previous episode to Demelza being eight months pregnant and then giving birth within minutes in the next. Fans on Twitter commented on this fast pace, with one stating, "if you are pregnant in Poldark times expect to have it in the next 10 minutes." This is similar to a previous character, Elizabeth, who went to full term in the gap between two episodes.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to ignore their relegation rivals and focus on their own performance. Following back-to-back wins, including a 3-2 victory at West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored an injury-time winner, the Foxes are three points from safety in the Barclays Premier League but remain bottom of the table. Pearson is wary of people becoming "overly optimistic" and believes his team's future is in their own hands.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record of 10,190 miles held by a humpback whale. According to Bruce Mate, the lead author of the tracking study, the migration is significant because Varvara, previously thought to be an endangered western gray whale, visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales. This suggests she may actually be an eastern gray, which could mean the population of endangered western gray whales (believed to be only 150) is even lower than estimated. Mate stated that this finding indicates a need to re-examine the genetic differentiation between the two species.

A 1,000ft stretch of seabed emerged overnight on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, near the town of Rausu. The new landmass, which measures up to 1,640ft long, 100ft wide, and has risen as high as 50ft, is believed by geologists to be the result of a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow. Local residents were surprised by the event, as they heard no sounds and felt no tremors. Authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further and do not believe it is related to earthquakes.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied claims that he will leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, stating that he loves the club, the city, and his teammates. This follows a recent falling out with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match. Van der Wiel says he wants to sign a new contract and has no reason to leave. However, the club is being linked with Dani Alves, which could result in Van der Wiel being sold.

Carlos Tevez wishes to leave Juventus to return to his former club, Boca Juniors, despite his contract with the Serie A champions running until 2016. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, has stated that Tevez must terminate his contract with Juventus before a deal can be completed. Although reluctant to lose the league's top scorer, who has 17 goals this season, Juventus have accepted Tevez's desire to leave and are identifying potential replacements. Tevez has always said he intends to finish his career at Boca Juniors, and his international manager, Tata Martino, stated a move would not be a "step down" or affect the player's future with the Argentina national team.

During a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola tore the left leg of his trousers, exposing his underwear. He later joked that he would need to buy new ones. In the match, Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1, after leading 5-0 at half-time, to book a place in the semi-finals. The goals for Bayern were scored by Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Porto had gone into the match with a 3-1 lead from the first game.

A three-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon involved ten people, including four children. A rescue helicopter flew a 40-year-old man, a 27-year-old woman, a five-year-old boy, and a six-year-old girl to the hospital. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. One person was trapped and had to be freed by fire crews using hydraulic cutting gear. The highway was closed for a few hours with diversions in place.

Ahead of a Sunday match against league leaders Chelsea, Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil showed off his new Apple Watch on Instagram, comparing it to the watch from the TV show *Knight Rider*. Arsenal, who trail Chelsea by 10 points, have been boosted by the return of midfielder Jack Wilshere from a five-month injury. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere is the "future of the club" but questions if he can stay fit, which has been an issue for the last three or four seasons.

Mark Clattenburg has been appointed to referee the Manchester derby at Old Trafford. This season, he has issued only two red cards in the Premier League, both to Manchester United players: Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw. He also sent off Manchester City's captain, Vincent Kompany, during an international match for Belgium. The derby is significant as United has moved one point ahead of City, and the match could decide who finishes second. Clattenburg is considered one of the Premier League's leading referees. His assistants for the match will be Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter released a statement accusing the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon like "a little black puppet on a string." Katter claimed the government assumed Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence and admitting to a criminal past. Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party but announced he would remain in parliament as an independent. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, said he sympathized with Gordon's position due to his own past experiences with racist attitudes. The statement drew criticism on social media for its terminology, but Katter defended his words, stating he used the term "black puppet" deliberately based on his personal experiences to call out what he perceived as "racial overtones."

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, creates dancing videos to inspire others and counteract stereotypes about people with disabilities. Having been bullied, she wants to show that while she may do things differently, she is the same as everyone else. Despite doctors initially warning she might never walk, Dayna now drives, attends college, and has started motivational speaking at local schools.

MLS side Orlando City has expressed interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who they believe would be a significant commercial draw for their large Latin-American fanbase. Hernandez, who is currently on loan at Real Madrid, is also being pursued by eight European clubs: Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan. Manchester United is reportedly willing to sell him for around £8 million.

Separately, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira after he rejected their initial offer. Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord have all contacted the midfielder's father about a potential signing.

At a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles around 12:15 am on a Saturday, a gang of at least three people set a white Dodge Charger on fire by pouring gasoline on it. The incident occurred after the driver had an argument with the suspects, who also allegedly attempted to carjack him at gunpoint. The driver and two passengers were not injured, but the car was completely ruined. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson, and the suspects are at large.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. According to a report from the Iowa Board of Chiropractic, Manuel also recommended that patients stop taking medication he had prescribed. He signed an agreement admitting to the charges and pledging not to seek license reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these actions, he received perfect five-star patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com based on three survey responses.

On a Tuesday over the Baltic Sea, a Russian SU-27 Flanker fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in what the Pentagon described as an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" due to aggressive maneuvers and high speed. The United States is filing a complaint with Moscow. A Russian Defense Ministry spokesman claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off, which a U.S. official said was false. This is not the first such incident involving these types of aircraft; a similar encounter occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of a Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City on March 27, just a week before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was in a hard case secured with padlocks and chains. Police believe a thief broke the car's window and used another vehicle to forcefully rip the case out. The agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen. Some of the bags and clothing were recovered at a hotel across the street, but the rifle has not been found. The hotel did not have surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his neighbour, Terrence Freebody, in Canberra in July 2012 by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him. According to forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen, Costa was believed to be suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse, which led to a "confused state" at the time of the murder. Evidence for this includes triple 0 calls Costa made during the incident and a trail of faeces at the crime scene. The prosecutor suggested Costa was feigning his memory loss. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset can be proven.

In Everton's 1-0 victory over Burnley, Ross Barkley missed a 10th-minute penalty, which was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper, Tom Heaton. Barkley took the penalty despite the presence of Leighton Baines, who has scored 15 of 16 penalties in the Premier League. Everton's manager, Roberto Martinez, defended the decision, stating he is happy for players to take responsibility and that Baines had allowed Barkley to take the kick. This incident was reminiscent of a previous match where Kevin Mirallas took a penalty from Baines and also missed. The missed penalty did not affect the outcome, as Mirallas scored the game's only goal in the 29th minute.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line's ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico. The cruise line stated that the deaths appear to be a murder-suicide. The discovery was made by the ship's cleaning staff at 11:30 a.m. on a Thursday. The FBI is investigating the incident. The ship was on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise that had departed from Tampa, Florida.

Patrick Kluivert, the coach of Curacao, has made a winning start in the 2018 World Cup qualifying. His team advanced to the second round in CONCACAF after defeating Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate. Curacao won the first leg 2-1 and drew the second leg 2-2, with a goal from Charlton Vicento in the 87th minute of the second match securing their progression. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round. Kluivert is a former Holland forward and was an assistant coach to Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso, a player who has won numerous major European competitions, believes that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be as significant as winning a trophy. At the time of the article, Leicester is at the bottom of the table, seven points adrift with eight games left. Cambiasso's past successes include winning 15 trophies with Inter Milan, such as the Champions League and five Serie A titles, as well as titles with River Plate and Real Madrid. Despite Leicester not having won a game since January, Cambiasso is convinced they can avoid relegation. He is on a one-year deal with the club and is happy in the East Midlands, suggesting he might stay beyond his current contract.

A 23-year-old mother-of-two named Gemma is at risk of being banned from seeing her children by her 52-year-old mother, Debbie. Gemma handed her two children, both under five, over to Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie is threatening the ban because Gemma refuses to stop drinking and partying, uses a legal high called MKat, and is suspected of stealing. Debbie claims Gemma stole an iPad from one of the children, and a lie detector test revealed she did steal. Debbie, who is raising the children alone after social services threatened to take them away, says the children call her "mum."

During a match against Manchester United, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored a goal to make it 1-0. In the build-up, Chelsea's John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on United's Radamel Falcao, leading to a loose ball that Cesc Fabregas collected to start the scoring move. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness all agreed that Terry's challenge was a foul and play should have been stopped. Souness said Terry used an elbow, Henry stated he would have wanted a foul, and Redknapp concluded that while Falcao could have been stronger, it was "still a foul."

On a Thursday morning, a tour bus carrying Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott caught fire on Interstate 30 in Texas. The fire was caused by a blown rear tire, and it burst into flames after everyone had evacuated. Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver were all safely evacuated. The other two band members were not on the bus. The fire destroyed the bus's back lounge, but Scott's Bible was spared. The band is still set to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing a space laser system that would use satellites covered in mirrors to harvest sunlight, convert it into laser light, and beam it down to Earth to boost the energy received by solar panels. This could make solar power viable in places like Scotland and help restore power to disaster areas. The lasers would not be powerful enough to be a weapon, though Dr. Quarterman has acknowledged a potential concern over who controls the satellites. The passage also mentions a separate proposal by Tokyo researchers to use a laser on the International Space Station to clear small pieces of space debris.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile, has gone on the run after vanishing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, at 6:15 pm on Tuesday. He was detained under a hospital order for sexually touching a three-year-old girl and for offences related to possessing indecent images of children. Described as having a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, Munden is 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, has dark hair, and may have shaved his beard. He also suffers from learning difficulties. Police have launched a manhunt to find him.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts following a lawsuit from Donald Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men and claimed that Donald Sterling used the couple's money to buy Stiviano gifts, including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano countered that there was nothing wrong with receiving the gifts. This event follows Donald Sterling's own downfall, where he was banned from the NBA and lost his team due to racist remarks he made to Stiviano that were captured on an audio recording.

Thierry Henry has criticised Arsenal's transfer dealings, urging his former club to purchase four top players: a goalkeeper, a centre back, a defensive midfielder, and a striker, in order to win the Premier League. Speaking as a Sky Sports pundit after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, Henry claimed that the Gunners cannot win the league with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker, despite Giroud doing "extremely well" and scoring 14 league goals. Henry used Chelsea's signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as an example of the quality of players needed.

A young woman who was abused for years by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn spoke at Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of the abuse. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim stated that she is scared for her future relationships, has suffered from depression since she was 14, and has been hospitalized for self-harm and an attempted suicide. She kept the abuse a secret until she heard he had been caught. During her statement, Van Ryn sat calmly and did not look at her. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, says he is feeling "better and better" as he prepares to return after more than a year out with a serious knee injury. His last first-team appearance was in March 2014. Gnabry is now closing in on a return, having recently played 90 minutes for the Arsenal Under 21s against Reading, and states he is over his injury worries.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling 70ft from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales. The incident occurred when he ran from a taxi to avoid paying the fare after a night out with friends. Mr. Phillips and his friends did not have enough money for the cab, so they told the driver they were going to an ATM before running off. In the dark, Mr. Phillips leapt over a fence, unaware of the cliff on the other side. His body was found the next morning by a dog walker. A coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating that Mr. Phillips was likely disorientated and did not know the danger he was in.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay fiasco have not received compensation, while the passport agency made a £42 million profit and its managers received bonuses up to £3,500. The delays were caused by a struggle to cope with 3.6 million applications, resulting in a backlog of over half a million passports. Ministers refused a blanket refund, and only 2,191 compensation applications were approved between April of last year and January of this year, for a total of £203,066. The Passport Office could not state how many claims were rejected due to a "system failure of our customer complaint database." A demand by the Home Affairs Select Committee for compensation was rejected by Ministers, who said it would "create a precedent."

A three-bedroom, semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, which has remained unchanged since the 1930s, is for sale with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. Described as a "collector's paradise," the house retains original features including stained-glass windows depicting ships and coats of arms, a wood-panelled hallway, oil-fired central heating, and a mint and black bathroom. The kitchen has its original 1930s cupboards, and a shelf in the hallway holds old tins of produce such as Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk and Colman’s Mustard. While the house has been double-glazed, auctioneers are concerned that the potential cost of renovations could deter developers. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his career as a backup quarterback for the 49ers. He became the starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Alex Smith suffered a concussion. That season, Kaepernick led the 49ers to the Super Bowl, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. This was the 49ers' first Super Bowl appearance since 1994.
"Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel. It was released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and later moved to Texas and then San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that connects the New Jersey Turnpike to the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, specifically NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn was raised in Leytonstone and Colchester, where he attended Stanway School, met Graham Coxon, and formed the band Blur. Blur's debut album, *Leisure*, was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. A band influenced by alternative rock, trip hop, and other genres released a self-titled debut album in 2001 to worldwide success. Albarn's debut solo album, *Everyday Robots*, was released on April 28, 2014, and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples of Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. As the capital, it is the base for many of the nation's important institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, from their 1992 debut extended play (EP) titled *Broken*.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is a BAFTA-nominated American screenwriter.

The provided text describes two properties titled "Shooter." The first is a 2007 film starring Mark Wahlberg as Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran framed for murder by a rogue private military company. The second is a TV series starring Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman in exile who is brought back into action to stop a plot to kill the president.
*House* (also known as *House, M.D.*) is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

In 1971, Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate. The murders were carried out by members of his group at his instruction. He was also convicted of the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After being charged, recordings of songs written and performed by Manson were released commercially.

Sean Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist born on August 17, 1960. His acting career began in 1974 with a television appearance on *Little House on the Prairie*. After his 1981 film debut in *Taps*, he gained critical attention for roles in crime dramas such as *At Close Range* (1986) and *Carlito's Way* (1993). He received his first Academy Award nomination for *Dead Man Walking* (1995) and had subsequent nominations for *Sweet and Lowdown* (1999) and *I Am Sam* (2001). Penn won the Academy Award for Best Actor twice, for *Mystic River* in 2003 and for *Milk* in 2008.

Sir Donald "Don" Bradman (1908-2001) was an Australian cricketer who is widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. After his retirement, he remained a pre-eminent figure in cricket for three decades, working as an administrator, selector, and writer.
L.A. Reid has served as the chairman and CEO of Epic Records, the president and CEO of Arista Records, and the chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer, best known for playing in the bands Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07). His career began in 1990 as the drummer for Greta. In August 1991, he co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, he plays in the band Prophets of Rage. The passage also states that a German heavy metal band named Rage was formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015. The show ran for 34 episodes over two seasons and was cancelled on November 14, 2014, four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas, serving from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she gained national attention for her keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was the second female governor of Texas and was defeated for re-election by George W. Bush. The passage also mentions a different Ann Richards, who was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
In 2011, Drake Bell independently released an EP called A Reminder.

"Boardwalk" is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books, including two novels, between 1984 and 2002.

Simón Bolívar (1783-1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader. He played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states independent from Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined region in the western part of the North Atlantic Ocean where a number of aircraft and ships are said to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began his career as a backup quarterback for the 49ers, taking over the starting position in the middle of the 2012 season after Alex Smith sustained a concussion. Marnie is an American psychological thriller film from 1964, directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an audio or visual form of marketing communication that uses an openly sponsored, nonpersonal message to promote or sell a product, service, or idea. It is different from personal selling because the message is not directed to a specific individual. Advertising is communicated through mass media, which includes old media like newspapers and television, and new media such as search results, blogs, and websites.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners play in three acts by Noël Coward. It is also a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan (1894-1986) was a British Conservative politician who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1957 to 1963.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira (384–322 BC). At seventeen or eighteen, he joined Plato's Academy in Athens, where he remained until the age of thirty-seven. After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, began tutoring Alexander the Great in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented a guitar pedal drum machine called the BeatBuddy and is the CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons. He was the first overall pick in the 1979 NBA draft and won a championship and an NBA Finals MVP award in his rookie season. He won four more championships with the Lakers in the 1980s. After several retirements, he played his final 32 games in 1996. In 2009, Ebony magazine named him one of America's most influential black businessmen; he has numerous business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers.

Formed in Los Angeles, California in 1994, Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. The band has released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). They first gained popularity in 1997 through their television series and by supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 - 27 March 1625) was the King of Scotland as James VI starting in 1567 and the King of England and Ireland as James I from 1603 until his death. Although he ruled both Scotland and England in a personal union, they remained individual sovereign states with their own parliaments and laws. He was a strong advocate for a single parliament for both kingdoms. While he achieved most of his goals in Scotland, he encountered significant difficulties in England, including the 1605 Gunpowder Plot and repeated conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the eighteenth series of the British reality show *Big Brother*, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Bentley, a British actor and voice-over artist, has narrated the show since 2000. He moved with the program from Channel 4 to Channel 5, and his Geordie accent has made his voice one of the most recognised in Britain.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany that borders the states of Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, and Bavaria, as well as the countries of Poland and the Czech Republic. It is Germany's tenth largest state by area (18,413 km2) and sixth most populous (4 million people). The state's history spans over a millennium. Saxony is also a quality wine region, one of the northernmost in Europe, and one of only two of Germany's 13 wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park is a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati, USA. "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown's solo career began with the release of her song "I Want You Back," a collaboration with Missy Elliott, on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley and Trace Cyrus.

"Mohra" is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. Released on July 1, 1994, it was the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Raveena Tandon was cast as a replacement for Divya Bharti, who had passed away after shooting some scenes. The film is also remembered for its chartbuster songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is also the title of singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is known for writing the 1987 film *Lethal Weapon* and for his 2005 directorial debut, *Kiss Kiss Bang Bang*.
"A View to a Kill" (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond spy film and was the seventh and last to feature Roger Moore as the MI6 agent.

Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, covering most of western New Guinea. It was formerly known as Irian Jaya, and before that, West Irian or Irian Barat. Previously, it comprised all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus probably died of natural causes, but there were unconfirmed rumors that he was poisoned by his wife, Livia.

Jennifer Lopez entered the music industry in 1999 with her debut album *On the 6* and the number-one single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number-one album (*J.Lo*) and film (*The Wedding Planner*) in the same week. Her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her 2002 album *This Is Me... Then*, and the film *Gigli* (2003) was a critical and commercial failure. She later married Marc Anthony, had a box office success with *Shall We Dance?*, and gave birth to twins in 2008. After an unsuccessful period, she returned to prominence in 2011 as a judge on *American Idol* and released her most commercially successful single, "On the Floor," which is one of the best-selling singles of all time.

A working animal is a typically domesticated animal trained by humans to perform tasks. Examples include assistance dogs, draft horses providing tractive force, and animals used for milking or herding. On rare occasions, wild animals are trained for work, often for entertainment, as they tend to lack the trustworthiness and mild temper of domesticated working animals.

"Billboard Dad" is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land. In exchange, backers have offered around 320 hectares of replacement land. There are conflicting expert accounts on whether the development would damage habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it "difficult to conclude" the replacement land is of equal value but does not oppose the development. A report by the developers claims a "net gain" in biodiversity, which the Gwent wildlife trust disputes. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, and Welsh government ministers will make the final decision.

On April 1st, the newspaper *Novaya Gazeta* reported that over 100 men suspected of being homosexual had been detained in Chechnya, and at least three were killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, stating that detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings. In response, Chechen Muslim clerics met on April 3rd, called the report an insult, and issued a resolution for "retribution," which the paper interpreted as a threat to its journalists. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations as "lies," and his spokesman claimed there were no gay people in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is helping people flee the persecution and says it will file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute.

Investing Solutions, a letting agent, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, were both founded by Samir Patel and are based in the same building. Fresh Start finds single homeless men and refers them to Investing Solutions for housing. The business model is described as "hugely profitable" because the agent houses multiple people in one property and claims individual housing benefit for each person, a total which is higher than the rent paid to the landlord. A homeless group has called this relationship "a new low," and a tenant described the properties as "wholly unsuitable," citing rats, damp, and lack of heating. Investing Solutions stated that "the bulk" of rents are passed to private landlords and that Fresh Start is an independent charity.

In a final warm-up match before their Eurobasket qualifying campaign, Great Britain's basketball team was defeated by the Netherlands. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon scored 13 for GB, while Worthy De Jong led the Netherlands with 18 points. GB led for most of the first three quarters, but the Netherlands scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to take a 71-60 lead and held on for the win. Coach Joe Prunty stated that the team "lost a little of our fire" but was pleased with the contribution of Gordon. GB's qualifying campaign begins with a game in Hungary in midweek.

The former five-weight world champion submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves instead of the regulation 10oz for the 154 lbs fight against Conor McGregor. The NAC, which also expected a request from McGregor, will debate the matter on August 16th.
