The London office of the Dundee-based Sunday Post is closing, marking the departure of Fleet Street's last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith. For decades, Fleet Street was the center of British journalism, where the first daily newspaper was published in 1702 and where most of the public received its information. The era was characterized by numerous pubs filled with journalists, smoke-filled newsrooms, and a male-dominated environment. The decline began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping, prompting most other national newspapers to leave by 1988 for cheaper, computerised printing technology. The former newspaper buildings have since been repurposed.

J.K. Rowling has received abusive comments on Twitter for her political views, including being called a "traitor" after donating £1m to the "No" vote campaign in the Scottish independence referendum. The author has blocked some abusive users she believed were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP) but has also had positive interactions with other SNP supporters. She believes there are more "decent people" than not and joked about bringing "marshmallows" to a suggested book burning. The passage also notes that the SNP won 56 of 59 seats in Scotland in a recent election, becoming the UK's third largest party.

A University of Edinburgh study found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off peers for the same crime. Poverty was also found to increase the likelihood of offending and violence. The study identified gender as a powerful predictor of violence, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts. A history of police contact was the strongest predictor of a young person not being in education, employment, or training by age 18.

A separate report showed that the recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefited the most deprived communities. In response, the Scottish government stated that Scotland is becoming a safer place, with crime at a 41-year low, and that it is tackling poverty and inequality.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday and was later pronounced dead. Robbie Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and has been remanded in custody. It is alleged that Mr. Walsh and two other men went to the estate looking for Mr. Haugh, which resulted in a fight where weapons were used. During the altercation, Mr. Haugh was stabbed in the back. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge. Gardaí recovered knives, golf clubs, and a knife blade with blood on it at the scene.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan posted a tweet questioning if Tom Elliott, a former UDR member, would reveal "how many people he harassed and shot as a member of the UDR." The tweet was deleted within an hour. At the High Court, it was stated that Mr. Elliott has a clear MoD record and the tweet was "untrue and wholly without foundation." Mr. Flanagan was ordered to post an apology on Twitter. The judge has reserved judgment on the amount of compensation, and the insurance firm for MLAs has refused to cover Mr. Flanagan for any compensation or costs. In a statement, Mr. Elliott said he had been "totally vindicated."

Hawick Knitwear, which employs over 230 staff, has increased its weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 to meet demand. This increase is driven by better-than-expected sales of its new Hawick Knitwear-branded range (launched in January) and growth in its business of supplying private label customers. The company, which dates back to 1874, was purchased by managing director Benny Hartop in November of last year. Hawick Knitwear sells to markets in Europe, including Sweden and Germany, and outside Europe, including the USA, Canada, and Japan.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. The driver, Brian Wright, 55, is on trial at Luton Crown Court, where he denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mr. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot remember if the traffic light was red. The prosecution states that his VW Golf failed to stop for a red light. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care, and the trial is ongoing.

A NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise, named "Dynamic Mongoose," is being conducted as a response to the growing threat from Russian submarines. In the exercise, 10 NATO warships are hunting a German U-boat, U33, which is acting as the enemy. The search involves warships, anti-submarine helicopters, and for the first time, a NATO research vessel using underwater drones. The passage highlights a "gaping hole" in Britain's defences, as it no longer has its own maritime patrol aircraft and must rely on allies. This is considered a "key vulnerability" as Russia invests heavily in its fleet of around 60 submarines, which are described as technologically advanced and the "quietest and most challenging adversary in the world." The exercise serves to prepare NATO for anti-submarine warfare and is a reminder that some nations, like Britain, cannot do it alone.

United Nations officials are warning of potential "genocide" and "ethnic cleansing" in South Sudan due to escalating violence that began in July. This has caused 340,000 people to flee to neighbouring Uganda, with an average of 2,500 new refugees arriving daily. Refugees report escaping killing, rape, and the targeting of civilians along ethnic lines, particularly Dinka against Equatorians and Nuer. Uganda has provided land and aid, creating massive refugee settlements like Bidi Bidi, but is now struggling to cope with the influx. A UN official has called for international pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the "massacre of civilians."

McKenzie, 38, is scheduled to fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. A former footballer for Norwich and Peterborough, he became a professional boxer in 2013 and has a record of eight wins and one draw. He is the son of former champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie.

A new Bridgwater Community Hospital is being built to replace the current one, which was constructed in 1813 and is now cramped and outdated. The total cost of the project is £33m, with funding coming from a £330m national NHS investment, NHS Somerset, and the Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray facilities. The proposed location is Bowers Lane, and the aim is to have the hospital finished by autumn 2014. In the last five years, three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced.

A man was fatally shot in the chest on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, at approximately 13:35 GMT. He was in or near a black Mercedes he had been driving. The victim was a member of a local family who were gathering for a celebration when the attack occurred. He was taken to Northern General hospital but died from his injuries. The passage also notes that there have been several other shootings in different areas of Sheffield in recent weeks.

The passage describes three main "virtual warrior" groups involved in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International, all of whom present themselves as independent activists.

*   **The Ukrainian Cyber Troops**, a pro-Ukrainian group led by Yevhen Dokukin, hacks Russian ministry servers, uses DDoS attacks on rebel websites, disrupts separatist funding, and hijacks CCTV and printers in rebel-held areas.
*   **Cyber Berkut** is an anti-Western group that hacks Ukrainian government websites and electronic billboards, and claims to have leaked data on US military aid and Ukrainian military losses. They also made an unverified claim about Ukraine's involvement in the downing of flight MH17.
*   **Anonymous International**, also known as Shaltay Boltay, is a Russian group that leaks Kremlin documents, some of which relate to Ukraine, such as a letter from a Russian fighter and emails from a rebel commander. It is unclear if they obtain material through hacking or from insiders.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, who is standing down as an MSP, shed tears during the farewell speeches of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond. Mr. Salmond, Mr. McNeil, and former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie are all standing down ahead of the 5 May election.

In his speech, Mr. Salmond repeated his belief that Scotland was "diverse, not divided" and concluded with the words, "goodbye from me... for now". Mr. McNeil, an MSP since 1999, used his address to warn that Holyrood needed to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding its committee system. Annabel Goldie also gave a speech, joking that she would miss her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care in residential homes in Wales. She is calling on pensioners, their friends, and families to share their experiences to help develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will highlight both good and poor care, examining factors like health, social relationships, and the environment. While the chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, supports the review's aims, he expressed disappointment that the advisory panel does not include a provider expert or anyone who has lived in, worked in, managed, or owned a care home.

In the year ending June 2016, Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group's pre-tax profit rose by £800,000 to £3.5m, despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures animal feeds and operates 19 Country Stores in Scotland, saw growth in international sales. While acknowledging that agriculture is challenging and the impact of Brexit is not yet fully understood, the company's board is confident it is well-positioned for future business challenges.

On Saturday afternoon, the body of a man in his 70s was found at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, and his death is being treated as murder. A man in his 80s was also taken to the hospital. Police want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin in connection with the offence and have warned the public not to approach him. A description of McLoughlin has been released, and police are conducting additional patrols in the area.

In a speech, David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, stated that the global economy is at a "delicate juncture" with a "weakening baseline." These comments follow weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, where exports have plunged by a quarter from a year ago. The IMF is likely to downgrade its current 3.4% global growth forecast in its next release of economic predictions in April. This situation has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that have bet on China's growth.

A new chain ferry has had a "frustrating and disappointing start" since its launch, having broken down, run aground, been suspended due to "training issues," and damaged cars. In response, the council has made the crossing free until 2 July and ordered a review of the project. A local shopkeeper stated that businesses are bearing the brunt of a loss of trade and asked about compensation, which a transport councillor said was "up for discussion." The councillor referred to the ferry as a "prototype" with "teething problems," adding that electrical and seamanship issues had been resolved and ramp extensions were authorised to prevent vehicle damage.

At about 07:30 GMT on Thursday, a multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott. A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until the early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an agency describing itself as an "international temp agency for beautiful and talented people," faced criticism for posting job advertisements with specific physical requirements, such as a personal assistant with "brown long hair with b-c cup" and a "sexy female driver." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called the ads "appalling, unlawful and demeaning," while women's equality campaigners and an employment lawyer also stated they were unlawful under the 2010 Equality Act. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice, stating "looks are important" to their clients, providing examples such as a client needing a specific cup size to fit a Christian Dior outfit. The agency's clients include MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods.

An office assistant named Mahesh allegedly shot two students at a hostel for the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. On Tuesday evening, he is alleged to have shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head, and then shot another student, Sirisha, who suffered severe injuries but is out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday and has been remanded until 12 April. The motive for the shooting is not clear. The passage notes that gun crime at schools in India is very rare.

Based on Glaad's "Where We Are on TV" study of shows from June 2016 to May 2017, there were 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, and the number of transgender characters rose from seven to 16. However, the group noted that more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington in *Orange is the New Black* and Bea Smith in *Wentworth*. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, attributed to shows like *Empire*, *Luke Cage*, and *How to Get Away with Murder*.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced he will not stand for re-election. This decision was made ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed, and after a majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him. Mr. Mackintosh was criticised over a loan made to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council while he was its leader. The loan, intended to rebuild Sixfields stadium, is now missing £10.25m and is subject to a police investigation for "alleged financial irregularities." The football stand remains half-built. Mr. Mackintosh has denied any wrongdoing.

In April, in the Dallas suburb of Balch Springs, 37-year-old policeman Roy Oliver fired a rifle into a car of teenagers driving away from a party, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. Police were at the party responding to reports of underage drinking. Oliver was sacked for policy violations a few days later. Police initially claimed the vehicle reversed "aggressively" towards the officer, but footage showed the car was driving forward, away from him. Oliver has been charged with murder, for which he faces five to 99 years in prison, and four counts of aggravated assault. He is currently free on bail, and no trial date has been set. If convicted of murder, he would be the first police officer to be so in Dallas county since 1973.

Melania Trump and her son, Barron, will delay their move to the White House to allow Barron to finish his school year. This decision has drawn both criticism and support on social media. A yellow wind warning has been issued with gusts of up to 75mph (120kmph) expected, particularly to the west of the mountains. The Giants defeated the Nottingham Panthers 4-3. The Giants' goals were scored by Derrick Walser, Mike Forney, Mike Radja, and James Desmarais. During the race, world champion Hamilton started from the back, broke his front wing on lap one, and made five pit stops. Raikkonen recovered to finish fifth, behind the Red Bulls of Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo. The race was shaped by a number of first-lap collisions which led to a safety car. Hamilton's car sustained damage to its floor and barge boards, and he now faces a 36-point deficit to Rosberg in the championship.

In an interview with the newspaper *Die Zeit*, prominent footballer Thomas Hitzlsperger announced he is gay to advance discussion on a topic he said was "simply ignored" in German football. His announcement was praised as a "courageous and correct decision" by former teammates like Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich. German football administrators, including former DFB president Theo Zwanziger and Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball, also supported him, calling it a "huge and courageous step" against homophobia. The announcement is considered a "watershed moment" in Germany, where homophobia in football is an acknowledged problem. The German Chancellor's spokesman, Steffen Seibert, also praised Hitzlsperger, stating that in Germany, "nobody should be worried about making his sexuality known."

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, helping Brighton achieve promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. With his one-year contract expiring, he is hoping to sign a new deal to remain with the team for their Premier League campaign, believing he has played well enough to earn it. Brighton's promotion is confirmed, and the team is now aiming to win the league title. Sidwell previously played for the club on loan in 2015-16 before signing his current deal in June 2016.

The football match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes, with Jamille Matt turning in a chip from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalised five minutes later from a corner, as Kurtis Guthrie scored from close range. Blackpool's goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, made two key saves, while both teams missed significant chances to win, with Colchester's Guthrie hitting the bar and Blackpool's Tom Aldred heading wide. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time.

The 29-year-old Reid made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season, during which they were relegated from League One. Reid, who has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, may make his debut for the U's in Wednesday's EFL Cup match against Aston Villa. Colchester started their season with a 3-1 defeat to Accrington.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer has prompted a "greater emphasis" on the need for a permanent memorial for police officers and staff. The memorial will be built at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire at a cost of £4m, with the government committing £1m and the UK Police Memorial Trust appealing for £1.5m. It is set to bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. The memorial, which is expected to be completed by 2019, will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out to be given to the families of fallen officers.

Following a 1-0 win at Sunderland, Manchester United are 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games remaining. The team has set a record with 25 wins in their first 30 matches and have won 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games. Their next league game is against Manchester City. Manager Ferguson will make changes for the upcoming FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea, as Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea suffered injuries or knocks during the Sunderland match.

Mr. Schmidt stated that Google pays the amount of taxes that is "legally required," which was £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. He believes it is the government's responsibility to change the tax system if it wants companies to pay more. Google has been criticised for minimising its UK tax payments by routing most of its UK sales through Ireland. In response to corporate tax arrangements, Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, has suggested a new committee to oversee the tax affairs of major firms in secret. Meanwhile, European Union leaders have agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities." Mr. Schmidt has also called for a debate on international tax reform.

The regulator, NHS Improvement, aims to reduce the NHS's £3.6bn agency staff bill by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap was introduced in October, limiting payments to 55% above normal shift rates for most staff, which has so far saved £600m. Despite this progress, the NHS is behind schedule on its target. NHS Improvement will start publishing "league tables" of trust spending and collect data on the highest-earning agency staff, as some hospitals have been quoted rates double the capped amount.

The Longford Town Centre, a symbol of Ireland's economic crash, is now showing signs of a slow recovery. A local trader, Matt O'Brien, has seen business increase after diversifying his shop's offerings. The main opposition party, Fianna Fáil, criticises the government for negligence, stating the Industrial Development Authority (IDA) has not brought any potential clients to Longford in over four years. In response, the government highlights the planned Center Parcs development, which hopes to employ 1,000 people but still needs planning permission. Despite signs of recovery, traders believe more could be done to boost local business, such as removing on-street parking charges.

The competition involves eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four sides qualifying for the play-offs. The final is on 29 May. The leading run-scorer is Warner (294), who is tied with De Villiers for the most sixes (12). The highest score in an innings is 108 by De Kock, and the player with the most wickets is McClenaghan (9). Four current or former England players are taking part: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The passage also lists fixtures from 25 April to the final on 29 May.

The number of plastic carrier bags has increased by 200 million since 2013. These bags often cannot be recycled, are thrown away after use, and end up in rubbish dumps and rivers, causing environmental problems. To address this, a 5p charge for plastic bags will be introduced in England from October to encourage people to reuse them. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, which already have a similar charge, have seen a decrease in bag usage. Campaigners hope the charge in England will reduce the number of bags being thrown away.

High winds across Wales caused a school roof to be ripped off in Rhosgadfan, power cuts for hundreds of homes, and travel disruption. The conditions led to train delays, restrictions on the Britannia and Severn bridges, and the cancellation of six Irish Ferries sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle, and Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed. The disruption occurred on a Friday, following a yellow weather warning for wind.

Michael B. Jordan is "super excited" for a role in the film *Black Panther*, which will be released in February 2018. The film reunites him with his *Creed* director, Ryan Coogler, and he will also work with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan did not specify what role he would play.

The east wing of Alexandra Palace is undergoing a £26.6m restoration project to transform it into a new cultural destination. This includes refurbishing a theatre, founded in 1875, and the BBC studios. The project is funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, which is raising the final £1m. The theatre, which has been unused for decades but retains its original decor and machinery, is hoped to reopen in 2018 for theatrical performances, cinema, comedy, and live music. The glazed east court will also be renovated to become a public and exhibition space.

James Milner, aged 30, won 61 caps for England's senior team after his debut in 2009 and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. He is also the most-capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. His only international goal was scored in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner described the decision he reached as "common sense" and wished the team success.

Marcy Smith's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by a fire started by rubbish in a wood stove. Her son, David, was awake on a FaceTime call and alerted his mother and sister, allowing the family to escape. Mrs. Smith credits her son with saving her and her daughter's lives. The family's dog and cats did not survive the fire, and the fire alarm did not go off. The family fled in their pyjamas and have since received donations of clothes and other items from the community.

An energy drinks giant was reportedly considering a £200m offer for the Premier League club, West Ham. The club's current owners, Sullivan and Gold, bought a majority stake in 2010 in a deal that valued the club at £105m and they now own over 85%. Since moving to London Stadium in August, the club has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Last year, Sullivan stated that a minority shareholding might be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold intend for their ownership to be passed on to their children.

At an awards ceremony in Los Angeles, *The Fault in Our Stars* was the big winner, taking home best movie. The film's star, Shailene Woodley, also won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Other winners included Bradley Cooper for best male performance, Channing Tatum for best comedic performance, Meryl Streep for best villain, and Zac Efron for best shirtless performance. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award, and Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award. The ceremony also acted as a promotional platform for upcoming summer films, showing clips from movies like the *Pitch Perfect* sequel and Marvel's new film *Ultron*.

Cammy Smith, 21, has been loaned to St Mirren from the Dons. He was previously on loan at Dundee United, where he has scored five goals this season. A Scotland Under-21 cap, Smith made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, scoring four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren boss Jack Ross described the move as a "brilliant acquisition," calling Smith a "good, mature boy" and a "good fit" who provides another "option in the attacking area." St Mirren, the Championship's bottom side, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to address potholes now that the weather is warm enough. The council aims to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be repairing drainage systems and clearing debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors were exposed to low levels of alpha radiation (NORM) on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes stated the workers were not wearing proper personal protective equipment (PPE) and now face cancer fears and ongoing blood tests. He accused EnQuest of a failure in its duty of care. EnQuest confirmed the incident, noting the exposure level was below the reportable threshold for the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), and said "additional precautionary steps" have been taken. Wood Group stated its commitment to employee safety. The HSE was made aware of the incident but confirmed it was not reportable and no investigation was carried out.

In 2007, the Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from a New York dealer, Art of the Past. The dealer's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, which was revealed during a 2012 court case. The sculpture is thought to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. After discussions and an official request from the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the ACM is returning the item. The museum noted that while there is no conclusive proof it was stolen from the temple, it acted on the dealer's confession. The ACM plans to take legal action to get compensation.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicentre in Garfagnana. The tremor was felt in cities including Milan and Florence, causing local power cuts and school evacuations, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The passage notes that Italy is prone to earthquakes, referencing a 2009 quake in L'Aquila that killed almost 300 people and two quakes in the same area the previous May that killed over 20. Following the L'Aquila quake, six scientists and an official were convicted of manslaughter for providing falsely reassuring statements about the risk.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, saw results from a fruit plant. He had been dubious about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate. The fruit is attached to the plant but is not yet ripe enough to eat. Mr. Grant said he was "literally jumping for joy."

Rockstar has delayed the release of their game from January 27th to March 24th to allow for "a few extra weeks of testing and polish." Before the PC release, online heists will be coming to consoles. The PC version will support 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and triple monitor configurations. The minimum specifications required to run the game have also been published.

A 76-year-old artist named Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)". The painting, which is about 7ft high, depicts a "leper squint," which the artist described as "holes made in the sides of medieval churches so the undesirables could look through to the service." Simpson, who was previously shortlisted for the prize in 1991, stated he would spend the prize money on art materials. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The offices of the newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, which support the governing AK Party, were attacked at almost the same time early on a Thursday. Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building, where a fire was quickly extinguished. Gunfire shattered windows at both buildings, which are 20km apart, and police found numerous spent bullet casings at both scenes. No casualties were reported. Police are hunting for the assailants, and no group has claimed responsibility.

A 24-year-old ex-Burton player, who was under contract with the Stags, will join the Mariners on a free transfer on 1 January. This is Marcus Bignot's first signing for the team. The player spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances.

Arsène Wenger, who has been linked with the England manager job, stated that he is focused on his current role. He commented that interim England manager Gareth Southgate has a good opportunity to get the job permanently and that competency is more important than having a "big name." Southgate succeeded Sam Allardyce in September and has two upcoming matches to persuade the Football Association. Wenger also announced that defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract, adding that Bellerin's long-term future is with the club. Additionally, midfielder Aaron Ramsey is expected to miss another "one or two" games due to a hamstring injury.

At approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday, a local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry, and the company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

A new charter arrangement will end a long-running pay dispute involving seafarers on two freight boats, the Hellier and Hildasay. The RMT union had claimed some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The new arrangement will see the contracted services return from Seatruck to the operator, Serco Northlink, from next month. Transport Minister Humza Yousaf stated that all crew members will now be paid at least the minimum wage.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell. After a confrontation between the two men, Mr. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault. Both he and his mother also admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying to police about the events. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Songwriter Rod Temperton died in London at the age of 66 after a battle with cancer. Nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, he wrote numerous hits, including "Thriller," "Off The Wall," and "Rock With You" for Michael Jackson, and "Boogie Nights" for his own band, Heatwave. Temperton, who began his career after working in a frozen food factory, won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. His private funeral has already taken place.

A team of researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader and Prof. Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, have discovered over 450 ancient geometrical earthworks, or "geoglyphs," in the western Brazilian Amazon, possibly 2,000 years old. Revealed by modern deforestation, the function of these sites is not well understood, but they are thought to have been used sporadically as ritual gathering places. Unlike other ancient sites, analysis indicates these geoglyphs were built amongst tall vegetation and were not visible above the forest canopy. The research challenges the idea that the Amazon was a pristine ecosystem before Europeans arrived, suggesting instead that ancient people transformed their environment by cultivating economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" whose legacy of "agroforestry" may still be evident in the biodiversity of the region's forests today.

The 21-year-old Australian, Nick Kyrgios, beat world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to move to the second round of the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios, ranked a career-high 12th, stated he felt "bored" and "very tired" during the match, attributing his fatigue to his recent Japan Open win, travel, poor sleep, and the long ride to the courts. At the previous year's Shanghai Masters, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst.

Scientists and charities are calling for the human papilloma virus (HPV) jab to be used to protect against head and neck cancers, as cases are increasing. The vaccine is currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer. Charities, including Tenovus Cancer Care, and organisations like BMA Cymru and Cardiff University's HPV research team, are delivering a letter to the Welsh government urging them to roll out the vaccination, specifically for boys. The Welsh government has stated it is waiting for recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before it will consider any changes to the HPV vaccination programme.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old with a rare blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, has died. His mother, Allison, announced his death on his Facebook page, "Jak's Journey," which he used to document his life and treatment, attracting over 28,000 Likes. Shortly before his death, a school prom was held in his honour, which he attended for 10 minutes. At the event, his family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. On January 23, doctors informed Jak and his family that the cancer had spread and they would not pursue further treatment. In the days following, his family urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

In a largely uneventful game, Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0. The winning goal was scored by Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Earlier, a goal by Uganda's Joseph Ochaya was disallowed for offside. The result means Uganda is eliminated from their first tournament since 1978, while Egypt will play Ghana for the top spot in Group D.

Lancashire County Council has earmarked land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station, following a comparative study by Network Rail. The plans, developed in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, could provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The chosen location is large enough for future expansion and has good highway access and connectivity. The council will now begin the process of acquiring the land. Skelmersdale's original station closed to passengers in 1956, and it is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without a railway station.
On Saturday morning, plants were found in a warehouse near Ashbourne, which police described as an "elaborate grow house." A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, late on Sunday after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent an emergency operation and was taken to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner later handed himself in to authorities and is now in custody. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is not yet clear, and police have called for witnesses.

A study by the Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The research, which analyzed 4,600 workers, found "no support" for the "reticent female" theory. When comparing like-for-like workers, men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study also found no evidence that women avoid asking because they are wary of upsetting their boss. However, it did find that women and men under 40 asked for and received pay rises at the same rate, which researchers suggest could mean negotiating behaviour is changing.

Oxford City Council is running out of burial space, with its two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council has been searching for a new site for many years and has used money for "ground investigations of possible sites," but all have been discounted due to issues like size, ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants. Once the current cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, use of reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible. The last time burial space was increased in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will offer visitors an app that uses augmented reality. By scanning items like signs and posters, users can access online content such as videos and band interviews on their phones and tablets. This feature is intended to enhance the experience for festival-goers and allow people worldwide to interact with the event. The lineup includes acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Lucy Spraggan.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage" after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. According to the British Horseracing Authority (BHA), such incidents are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia (over-heating and wobbling), but he had never collapsed before and did not show these symptoms on the day he died. A report concluded the haemorrhage was the cause of death, despite questions about a link to his previous condition. His past wins included the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

In the autumn of 2004, a 15-year-old girl was raped in a Portsmouth garage. The defendant, David Ayrton, who is now 34 and called Davina, denied the charge. She will be sentenced on March 4th and has been remanded into custody at a male prison, as the judge deemed her a risk to herself and a risk of failing to attend sentencing. The court heard that Ayrton has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer, and changed her name in 2012, but has not made any physical changes to her body or taken medication. In 2014, she told a care home worker about the attack. The victim stated she had drunk very little and clearly recollected the events.

In Rio, the Serbs were defeated 6-4 6-4 by Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares. This loss followed a day after Djokovic was eliminated from the singles by Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, the 29-year-old world number one and 12-time Grand Slam winner, had previously lost in the third round of Wimbledon to Sam Querrey but went on to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US are scheduled to participate in a carving event in Carrbridge on Saturday. Using only chainsaws, they will carve logs into the shapes of animals and people. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will be returning to defend his title and the first-place prize, the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, is recovering from a serious foot injury sustained in September and is close to a return. He is currently "back up and running" and hopes to be fit for the Six Nations tournament, which begins on February 7. Webb has also renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay at his "home region" and put himself in the "best possible position to play for my country."

On Tuesday morning near Sumas, Washington, US border agents interrupted an attempt to smuggle 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. Agents encountered two men with backpacks; one, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested immediately, while the other, Nathan Hall, fired a weapon and fled. Hall was later arrested in British Columbia. Two accomplices, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco for a payment of $11,000. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.

In the past year, the NSPCC's Childline service counselled over 4,500 children for online abuse, an increase from approximately 2,400 in 2011-12. Children as young as seven reported being tormented and scared to go to school. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, called the figures a "wake-up call," stating that cyber-bullying follows children home and becomes a "persecution they cannot escape." She stressed that it is imperative for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene, for schools to take the issue seriously, and for children to seek help, as bullying does not stop on its own. The report was released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week.

A vote by the Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee to authorize 492 new homes in settlements was postponed at the request of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office. The move was intended to avoid further straining relations with the US ahead of a speech by Secretary of State John Kerry. This follows a UN Security Council resolution, which the US did not veto, calling for an end to settlement construction. The resolution infuriated Mr. Netanyahu, whose spokesman accused the White House of helping draft it, a claim the US state department denied. In response to the UN vote, Israel summoned ambassadors from supporting countries, recalled its own from New Zealand and Senegal, and cut aid to Senegal. The UN resolution stated that the settlements, considered illegal under international law, have "no legal validity" and are a "major obstacle" to peace. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said the resolution "paves the way" for an upcoming peace conference.

Based on the text provided, the passage covers the events and tributes surrounding the Queen's 90th birthday. Key events include the release of a new stamp featuring four generations of the Royal Family, a visit by the Queen to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, and the opening of a new bandstand. In a BBC interview, Prince William paid tribute to the Queen as a "guiding example" and addressed criticism of being "work-shy," stating he takes his duty seriously but is finding his own way into the role with the support of his family. The passage also notes that the republican group Republic criticized the BBC's coverage of the birthday.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0. Two quick first-half goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew gave the Premier League side control. Sakho's goal was assisted by Sam Byram. Cheltenham had chances from Harry Pell, Jordon Forster, and Dan Holman but did not sufficiently test the West Ham goalkeeper. West Ham could have won by a greater margin, but Angelo Ogbonna's header was cleared off the line. The two sides' only previous meeting was four years ago, a 2-1 win for West Ham. Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a motorcycle collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. The crash was caused by Andreas Werner, 46, who failed to spot the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not want Werner to be jailed, accepting it was a "momentary lapse."

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from London considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists, traveled to Syria and joined the Islamic State-affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed. He was a public fighter online, appearing in propaganda videos and was pictured holding a bag containing a severed head. Last June, he attempted to sneak back into the UK by faking his own death online and having his cousin drive to Bulgaria to retrieve him. Police were waiting for them at Dover and arrested them. Khawaja has admitted to four offenses and faces a possible life sentence, while his cousin has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Kayden Jackson, 22, has signed for Barnsley, becoming their third signing for the next season. He joins from Wrexham, where he scored four goals in 36 appearances last season and turned down a new contract offer. Wrexham finished eighth in the table. Barnsley's caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, said Jackson has "pace to burn" and "likes to get at defenders."

Bottles of 'Vanish' began washing up at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard on Sunday, and have also affected other nearby coves. National Trust volunteers are clearing the bottles, which are said to pose a risk to wildlife, and some have reportedly leaked. The National Trust believes a container went overboard from a ship. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed that the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of 'Vanish' bottles in May, but stated there is currently no evidence to link it to the bottles on the coast, calling the evidence "circumstantial." Cornwall Council has advised the public to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not to attempt to recover them.

An incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00, causing minor injuries to several people. The road was closed with diversions put in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland's inquiries into the incident are ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton. Last season, he made 14 appearances, helping the team finish second in League One and secure promotion to the Championship. Dervite, who joined from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in total, was praised by manager Phil Parkinson for his "excellent contribution." David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan have also signed new contracts with the club.

The Liberal Democrats and the Labour party, who had previously cooperated to defeat the government on Brexit amendments concerning EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval, had a falling out. The disagreement occurred after MPs rejected these amendments, with the Lib Dems wanting to insist on them while Labour was prepared to defer to the Commons.

The Lib Dems accused Labour of being prepared to "concede everything" and "waving through the government's plans." In turn, Labour accused the Lib Dems of giving people "false hope" and "grandstanding" for campaign leaflets. Despite a history of alliances on other issues, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions" and a "business-like" future relationship, while a Lib Dem spokesperson said they would continue to work with peers on issues they agree on.

Based on the passage, defence is a low priority for most political parties and the electorate, ranking behind the economy, the NHS, and immigration. Despite a world perceived as more dangerous, the UK has made significant cuts to its armed forces, reducing the size of the Army, Navy, and RAF, which has created "capability gaps."

The UK's defence spending has fallen from fourth to sixth in the world, and it is projected to drop below the NATO commitment of spending 2% of GDP, which could damage its credibility with allies like the US. Further cuts are considered likely as the defence budget is not protected by the main parties.

Key policy issues lack consensus. The renewal of the Trident nuclear deterrent is a major point of division, with parties proposing everything from a full replacement to scrapping it entirely. Additionally, while two new aircraft carriers are being built, there are concerns they will be under-crewed and under-equipped, leading to a "hollow force" and making it harder for Britain to "punch above its weight" militarily.

Barcelona is being investigated for the transfer of Neymar, with a judge in Spain ruling there is sufficient evidence to proceed. The club paid £48.6m for the player, with his parents receiving £34m, and the total cost is estimated to be £106.8m. Club president Sandro Rosell resigned following accusations of misappropriating money, which he denies. While insisting they have committed no offense, Barcelona made a "complimentary tax declaration" of over 13.5 million euros to cover "eventual interpretations" of the contracts. It is not yet confirmed if the case will be dropped following this payment.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father, was killed when the van he was a passenger in was hit by a car driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Following the incident, Mr. Luciw's family and the van's injured driver have called for regular driving tests or medical examinations for retired people, arguing that reactions slow with age. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must self-assess every three years to renew their license. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) stated it has no plans to restrict licensing by age, as "evidence does not show that older drivers are more likely to cause a serious accident than others." Age UK also commented that it is "vital" for older people to be able to drive for their independence.

Many women have questioned the safety of mesh implants used for incontinence after suffering debilitating side effects. An independent review of the implants produced a controversial final report, causing two patients and a consultant to quit the review group in protest, with the patients calling it a "watered-down report". The chairwoman of the review, Tracey Gillies, apologised for failing to unite the panel.

The report's recommendations, which will be implemented, include that the procedures should not be offered routinely for pelvic organ prolapse, that patients be offered a range of treatments to make "informed choices," and that reporting of adverse events be mandatory. The health secretary stated the government does not have the power to ban the procedures.

An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, will now examine the process by which the report came to its conclusions. Over the past 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have had these implants, and over 400 are currently taking legal action.

At the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, 23-year-old Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old record by 14 seconds, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially raised concerns about whether the race met the criteria for a record, as Muir was the only competitor to finish the 5K and she questioned if drug testing was in place. However, British Athletics confirmed the time is expected to be ratified as official. McColgan said she was excited to see her record broken by Muir, a fellow Scot, and believes Muir has the ability to run even faster and win world medals. Muir also broke her own British 1500m record in Paris and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won the event aboard his horse, Sam. Astier Nicolas of France won silver, and Phillip Dutton from America took the bronze. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, competing 10 months after being in an induced coma. Fox-Pitt led after the dressage phase, but a disappointing cross-country performance ruined his medal bid, despite a faultless final show-jumping round. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished in ninth place.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in a match lasting two hours and 39 minutes. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set, but Murray won five games in a row to secure the victory and a place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the next round on Monday. In other results, Johanna Konta beat Maria Sakkari 6-4 6-1. Murray described the match as "tense" and "up and down," and was pleased to win before darkness might have forced a delay to close the roof.

Following a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, it was found that alcohol was being served outside of licensing hours, with receipts showing sales as late as 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of this offence, and James Thomas was charged with one count. The judge ordered the bar to be closed for three months, fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000, and fined Mr. Thomas £1,000. The judge described Ms. O'Neill as having "an appalling record" and called it "as bad a case as I have come across."

At the launch of the Ulster Unionist party's manifesto, leader Mike Nesbitt stated, "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." The party had intended for the election to be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle, but the focus shifted to Mr Nesbitt's comments. A senior colleague, Danny Kennedy, publicly distanced himself from the remarks, to which Mr Nesbitt responded with a joke. Mr Nesbitt denied any regrets, said he "wouldn't withdraw a word," and confirmed he would rather go into a partnership with the SDLP than Sinn Féin.

The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', includes calls to tackle waiting lists, increase PSNI numbers, prioritise the York Street interchange, stand up for the LGBT community, and ensure no group is worse off due to Brexit. It also has a section on 'Cleaning Up Stormont'. Mr Nesbitt described the election as being about "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption," hoping this message would resonate more than the controversy over his remarks.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed that a motion will go before the Northern Ireland assembly for approval to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. This move aims to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales, where a similar law is dubbed 'Turing's Law'. The motion is expected to allow for pardons both posthumously and for living gay and bisexual men who apply. The minister has secured executive agreement for the motion, stating it is an opportunity to "right the wrongs of the past" and will now go forward for consideration by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in a mile race with a time of 4:19.12, behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This time set a new Scottish record, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 effort, and placed Muir second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd. Muir, who is also a veterinary student, now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She recently won an 800m race in France, will compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm next, and hopes to secure a place for Great Britain in the Rio Olympics at the upcoming British trials.
Based on the text provided, the passage is about pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that are ranked as having "most excellent" water quality.

According to Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC, the Russian state was the "likely" sponsor in the 2006 murder of Mr. Litvinenko, who died after drinking tea containing polonium-210. The suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, are believed to have had no personal motive. Mr. Horwell stated that potential motives for the Russian state included Mr. Litvinenko's defection and his personal attacks on President Putin, but stressed this did not mean Putin was involved. The suspects, who deny wrongdoing, left a "trail of polonium" but remain in Russia as extradition attempts have failed. The passage also notes that Mr. Litvinenko was poisoned twice and the long-term risk to the public from the polonium exposure will never be known.

Steve Smith, 26, is succeeding the retiring Michael Clarke as captain of the Australian Test team. Smith already leads the one-day side and will also captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, has been named vice-captain, a role he was given despite a history of disciplinary problems because selectors believe he has matured. Clarke, 34, retired after his team surrendered the Ashes to England. Smith has previously captained the side in three Tests against India when Clarke was injured.

When asked three times on Channel 4 News if he believed homosexual sex was a sin, Mr. Farron refused to answer directly, instead stating, "my firm belief is we are all sinners." On the BBC's Andrew Marr Show, he said he was "passionate about LGBT-plus rights," that defending equal marriage would be "at the top of my agenda," and that he wanted to extend marital rights for transgender people. When asked why he voted against the 2007 Equality Bill, he said it was because an amendment tabled by the Lib Dems concerning "protection of individual liberties" was defeated, though he did not specify what those concerns were.

In 2015, French-based Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, leading to the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare is now taking over the plant for its pharmaceutical production, with the hope of re-hiring many former Sanofi employees. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the area and boost the local economy. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company that develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to about 60 countries.

Richard Ellis, the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving on Friday at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are also leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the opposition SNP group leader, said the departures were indicative of the council's inability to retain senior staff and that he expected more to follow. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their "dedication and professionalism".

Militants armed with guns and grenades attacked the 400-bed Sardar Daud hospital in Kabul. The attack began when one militant detonated explosives at a gate, after which the attackers opened fire on staff and patients. The so-called Islamic State (IS) group claimed responsibility for the attack, while the Taliban denied involvement. After several hours of fighting, commandos killed all four attackers. The defence ministry stated that more than 50 people were wounded. The attack is considered a change in approach for IS in Afghanistan, as it was the first time they had directly engaged with security forces in the capital, using a method more commonly associated with the Taliban.

After crashing at this year's TT and experiencing mechanical problems with the Fireblade bike, the English rider Martin clarified his racing plans. He stated on Facebook that while he has not given up on road racing, he has no plans to race on the Hondas again this year. He described the TT as a "bloody disaster" and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix, as he told his team the bike would not be competitive. He now wants to race "classics and oddball stuff."

Based on the passage provided, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 declared governorships, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. This follows the PDP's loss in the presidential election to the APC's Muhammadu Buhari. The PDP, which won eight governorships, has been relegated to a regional party with strength in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The APC made historic gains, winning in key northern states and the commercial hub of Lagos, but failed to win in any of the five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for the incoming president. The election in Taraba is still outstanding, and the one in Imo was declared inconclusive. The PDP's decline is attributed to its 16 years in power, defections, corruption allegations, and its failure to end the Boko Haram insurgency.

Based on the passage, a US-based environmental group named Mighty has accused agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore's state-owned investment company Temasek, of encouraging unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to haze from fires in Indonesia. Mighty's report alleges Olam created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" and is also clearing rainforests in Gabon.

Both Olam and Temasek reject the allegations. Olam states it has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and has released its list of 14 suppliers, noting that a full vetting process will take several more years. Temasek stated that it supports no-burn policies but does not direct the business operations of its portfolio companies. The passage also notes that the palm oil industry globally has a troubled track record regarding environmental and labor practices.
A restaurant has begun serving puppy platters after a new law was introduced allowing dogs to eat at restaurants, as long as they are outdoors.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to a knee injury. Derby County striker David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing the last game. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after scoring as a substitute.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube, which was imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 after the film "Innocence of Muslims" was uploaded. The ban was lifted because Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the site. According to Pakistan's ministry of information technology, the government can request that Google block "offending material" for users within Pakistan. However, a YouTube spokeswoman clarified that government requests for content removal are not automatically granted, will be thoroughly reviewed, and will be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report. While many young Pakistanis have welcomed the decision, some activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms of the agreement between Google and the government.

LFA boss Musa Bility is demanding that Domenico Scala, the head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, withdraw from his position due to a conflict of interest. The conflict arises because Scala is Swiss-Italian, the same nationality as presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility points out that Scala excused himself from the 2015 elections for sharing nationality with candidate Sepp Blatter and has threatened to take the matter to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. However, a spokesman for Scala argues there is no conflict of interest, stating that Scala's previous withdrawal was a voluntary measure taken only because the candidate was the incumbent president. The election to replace Sepp Blatter, featuring five candidates, is scheduled for 26 February.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments on Monday morning, where they are believed to have been working in a paint-spraying area. Evidence suggests a flashover explosion, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, led to their deaths. The company, which makes buckets for diggers, has undergone a forensic search, and the Health and Safety Executive is also gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after complaining to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) about a contentious penalty in their 2015 quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea. Tunisia had to apologize to be allowed to participate, clarifying that they never accused Caf of corruption but rather that the referee was "badly chosen." Meanwhile, Morocco was able to enter the 2017 qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban that had been imposed on them for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears. Cas also reduced Morocco's fine from $1m to $50,000.

Following a mass fracas in the 95th minute of a game that Chelsea won 3-1 at Etihad Stadium, both Manchester City and Chelsea have been charged. City's Sergio Aguero received a four-match ban for a challenge on David Luiz, and his teammate Fernandinho received a three-match ban for clashing with Cesc Fabregas. Fabregas will not face any further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologised for the incident, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Based on the text provided, here is a concise summary:

Wales has some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world, partly because patients with non-urgent or unclear symptoms face long delays for diagnosis. To address this, a pilot scheme, inspired by a successful Danish model, is being launched in Cwm Cynon and Neath.

Under the scheme, GPs who suspect a patient has cancer can refer them directly to a new diagnostic centre, even without clear symptoms. The goal is for patients to be seen within seven days and receive multiple tests on the same day, speeding up diagnosis and allowing for earlier treatment. The Cwm Cynon pilot will last for six months, and if successful, the service will be rolled out to other health boards.

England won the cricket match against Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series. England's scores were 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, while Pakistan was bowled out for 198 and 234. This was England's second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs.

Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, as well as taking four catches and one wicket. Captain Alastair Cook, who scored 105 and 76 not out, called Root's performance "as good an innings as I've seen."

Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed disappointment, stating the team was "short of confidence" and that "shot selection really cost us." The third Test will begin on August 3rd at Edgbaston.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, taking interim coach Rob Howley with him as part of his backroom team. Consequently, forwards coach Robin McBryde will become Wales' head coach for the third time for the summer tour. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches to support McBryde and believes the experience will be a developmental opportunity that benefits Welsh rugby.

Hull City came from behind to defeat Southampton 2-1. Southampton initially led with a sixth-minute penalty from Charlie Austin. Hull, who lost strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries, scored two goals in two second-half minutes. Substitute Robert Snodgrass scored the first and then assisted Michael Dawson for the second. Hull goalkeeper David Marshall made a string of saves, and Sam Clucas made a goalline clearance in the final minute to secure the victory. The win was Hull's first in the league since August 20, ending a six-game losing streak.

At approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, a motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor. The motorcyclist was a local resident, and the tractor driver was not injured. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

Macedonia's President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims that were revealed by covert recordings, stating he wanted to "put an end to the agony" before elections. The move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev called the move illegal and urged protests, while EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn said the action was not in line with the rule of law and put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. The crisis stems from recordings released by Mr. Zaev in 2015, which he claims show ministers plotting vote-rigging, covering up a murder, and reveal the government wiretapped 20,000 people. The government denies the accusations and has accused Mr. Zaev of trying to "destabilise" the nation.

Following the sacking of Bob Bradley, Curtis and Paul Williams are taking temporary charge of Swansea for their match against Bournemouth. The club wants to appoint a new manager as soon as possible, with Paul Clement being the first choice. Curtis expressed concern about a potential relegation, stating it would be difficult to return to the Premier League from the now-stronger Championship. He believes the club has lost its "Swansea Way" since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 due to frequent managerial changes and not adequately replacing players. However, Curtis feels the current squad is good enough to stay up and reminds new players of the club's history to impress upon them the importance of avoiding relegation.

A victory for Leyton Orient relegated Dagenham & Redbridge to the National League. Jay Simpson scored two goals for Orient, and while Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona scored for Dagenham, Armand Gnanduillet fired in the winner. The result keeps Orient's play-off hopes alive, leaving them two points adrift of the spots, while Dagenham returns to the National League under manager John Still, the same manager who previously took them to League One. Dagenham has League Two's worst goal difference, and striker Jamie Cureton's goal tally dropped to nine from 20 the previous season. Still has committed to helping the club gain promotion next season. The win for Orient came four days after player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed from his managerial role.

Steven Gerrard, the 36-year-old former Reds captain, will return to his former club as a youth coach in February. This is his first job since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. According to Klopp, Gerrard wants to be a manager in the future and is taking steps to learn the job. Gerrard had previously been linked with the manager's job at MK Dons but said the opportunity came "too soon." He is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence.
McManus scored two goals for Morton, with Ross Forbes and Denny Johnstone also scoring to ensure a comfortable win for the hosts. Kyle McAusland scored Alloa's goal before half-time.

Ofsted has closed three places in Birmingham where children were being taught in squalid conditions. This is part of an investigation into 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands. The owners of the closed establishments are being investigated for running an illegal school, which could result in a jail term of up to 51 weeks. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, believes this is the "tip of the iceberg" and is concerned about the risk of abuse or radicalisation. In response, the government has funded a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the education secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution. Ministers are also consulting on regulating places that teach for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael stated that the investigation will apply to all religious groups.

Lilliard Gin is a distillery located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. Described as a small-scale operation fitting into a cowshed with one of the UK's smallest production stills, it is the first new distillery in the Borders in nearly 200 years. According to lead distiller Kate Macinnes, the gin aims to use wild, local botanicals from the Teviot valley to convey a "true sense of the local flavour palette." The name "Lilliard" is taken from the heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor and was chosen to reflect the landscape and the distillery's "strong female production team."

In August 2013, Gary Green, 51, reversed a vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm, causing his death. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation, as the incident occurred on private land, and was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, said her family had been "changed forever." An HSE inspector described the case as "extremely tragic" and Green's behaviour as "reckless."

Following a ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), 27-year-old Uruguay striker Luis Suarez can now train and play in friendly matches for his new club, Barcelona. The ruling partially overturned a FIFA ban for biting Giorgio Chiellini. While Cas "generally confirmed" the sanctions, it deemed banning him from all "football-related activities" as "excessive." Suarez is still banned from "organised" matches and must serve the remainder of his nine-match competitive international ban. His competitive debut for Barcelona is anticipated to be on October 26 against Real Madrid. He will be publicly presented as a Barcelona player on Monday and is available for Uruguay's upcoming friendlies.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a 380-metre race in which competitors carry another person over obstacles like haystacks and a steep slope while dodging water pistols. They beat Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. Competitors do not need to be married, and the race saw various combinations of participants. Richard and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

In October, the paper car tax disc will be replaced with an electronic system that allows for monthly direct debit payments. This change raised concerns about job losses for the 5,000 workers at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) in Swansea. In a letter to Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, minister Stephen Hammond stated that while job roles will change, any reduction in staff numbers will be managed by redeploying employees to other growth areas rather than through redundancies. Mr. Hedges welcomed this assurance, saying it would "give comfort" to DVLA employees.

A Hungarian minister, Mr. Szijjarto, has stated that the country will not backtrack on three issues, calling them "domestic issues" that the EU should not interfere with. The EU objects to Hungary's controls on asylum seekers and non-governmental organisations (NGOs), as well as a higher education law that critics say could lead to the closure of the Central European University. Thousands of Hungarians have protested these laws. Mr. Szijjarto said that Poland has promised to veto any EU move to strip Hungary of its voting rights, a decision which requires unanimous approval.

An unnamed star will play Mrs. Potts and Kevin Kline will play Maurice. Emma Watson has been cast as Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, Luke Evans will be Gaston, and Josh Gad will play LeFou. The film, directed by Bill Condon, begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

Adrian Gill, a columnist for the Sunday Times since 1993, has died from cancer, which he had described as the "full English". His editor, Martin Ivens, called him a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. Gill, who had dyslexia and dictated his copy, wrote a final column about his diagnosis. While his writing was popular and praised by colleagues, his articles often caused controversy, including comments about the Welsh, Clare Balding, and an incident where he shot a baboon. He was previously married to Amber Rudd and was engaged to his partner Nicola Formby at the time of his death.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was allegedly attacked by a Russian diplomat in Ulan Bator after performing on stage wearing a Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika. According to his father, Sukhbaatar was hit with a metal object, spent 10 days in a coma, and suffered a serious brain injury. The swastika is a traditional symbol in Mongolia that pre-dates the Nazis. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but called press reports "distorted." A police spokesman stated the suspect is a Russian diplomatic officer who was not detained because the injury was "not serious," and that the case is under investigation.

On Monday at 03:30 BST, campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid held a demonstration on the northern runway to protest the airport's expansion plans. The protesters have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area and are scheduled to appear in court on August 19th. The Metropolitan Police have stated that airport security will be reviewed.

In a cricket match, Nick Selman scored 101 runs for Glamorgan, his second first-class century and a return to form after being dropped on eight. Despite his century, seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets for Gloucestershire. In their turn to bat, Gloucestershire struggled, and the day ended with the match evenly balanced. Glamorgan is being led by Michael Hogan for the first time in the absence of Jacques Rudolph.

Craig Hughes, 33, was arrested after making online threats to the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He said he planned to make a false report to ambush and shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary. The threats were made on two occasions while he was drunk. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and is awaiting sentencing. He has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm and was on bail for other firearms offences (of which he was later cleared) at the time of the threats. His legal team stated he would not have carried out the threat.
