After being reduced to 8-2, Surrey scored 255-7, thanks to a 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Davies was dropped on 43. In response, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Their run-chase was undermined by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, who dismissed Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Tim Bresnan top-scored for Yorkshire with 68. The loss meant Yorkshire failed to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002.

At 07:00 BST, the crew of a 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed the coastguard because their vessel was taking on water and its pump could not cope. The RNLI lifeboat crew responded by placing a pump on the boat and towing it to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will not compete for Scotland at the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast because the April event conflicts with her veterinary medicine exams in May. At the recent World Athletics Championships, she finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m, setting a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. Muir is "gutted" to miss the Commonwealths but says the World Indoor Championships in March are "potentially a target" and that she has "at least two, even three more Olympics" in her future.

According to football pundit Robbie Savage, Liverpool are a long way from repeating their previous season's title challenge and will have to work hard just to get into the top four. The key reasons for this decline include:

*   The loss of Luis Suarez and injury to Daniel Sturridge, with their replacements (Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini) being "not good enough."
*   A subsequent drop in intensity, pressing, and first-half goals.
*   A lack of "runners going past their striker from midfield."
*   A dramatic drop in goals from set-pieces.
*   Persistent defensive weaknesses and a lack of leadership at the back, despite heavy spending on players like Dejan Lovren.

Savage also discusses Steven Gerrard, stating that at 34 he faces a physical and mental battle to extend his career. However, Savage believes Gerrard is not "finished" and remains one of Liverpool's most important players.

A £45m facility, containing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre, is to be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock. East Ayrshire Council intends to ask the McIlvanney family for permission to name the campus after the writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, who was an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975, was known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" and wrote works including the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty, and The Big Man. He was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster, and died at his Glasgow home on December 5th.

A sea mine, believed to be a British device from the 1940s or 1950s, was discovered on Monday, leading to the evacuation of three streets near a swimming pool. An exclusion zone was established on the river and at sea, and residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, as the mine's deterioration made it impossible to determine how much explosive material it contained. The mine is being moved to a safer location by experts. The incident also caused disruption to some ferry services.

A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo 2020 Games, which is £2m less than the amount allocated for the Rio Games. UK Sport has set a medal target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals.

Badminton is the only sport that won a medal in Rio to have its funding completely removed, a decision the Badminton England chief executive called "staggered" and "incomprehensible." Archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby also missed out on funding, while cycling's funding was cut by over £4m. In contrast, judo, which also won a bronze medal, had its funding increased.

UK Sport's CEO, Liz Nicholl, stated that they must "prioritise to protect and enhance the medal potential." Funding for five new Olympic sports and two new Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 has yet to be confirmed.

Three Victorian hotels in East Cliff, Bournemouth—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View—will be demolished to be replaced by a six-storey, 90-room hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks with 122 apartments. Councillors voted seven to three in favour of the plan, stating it would help tourism and improve living for older people. English Heritage, the Ancient Monuments Society, and 49 residents objected, citing that the scale of the development would cause "severe harm" to the designated conservation area. The council also received 246 letters supporting the plans.

Jake Vallely, 24, punched and beat off-duty soldier Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, during a night out in Brecon. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December, while his friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Pte Boyd, who served with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was in town for training exercises. The attack occurred outside a bar called The Cellar after Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and was boasting he was the "hardest man in Brecon". A family tribute described Pte Boyd as an "all-rounder" with a "promising career" and stated that Vallely had created "a void in our family that will never be filled".

Following an error where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations due to their names being missing from the poll list, Chief Executive Andrew Travers left the authority by "mutual agreement." The council has launched an independent investigation, which will conclude by the end of May and present its findings publicly. Deputy Chief Executive John Hooton is taking over the role temporarily. The council apologised and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents, while Mr. Travers blamed the electoral registration lists for the problems.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored a free-kick for Gateshead, and Sean Newton scored a free-kick for Wrexham, making the score level before half-time. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead with a header from a cross.

Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, credited the win to his team passing the ball better in the second half. Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment, stating his team's second-half performance was not as good as its first and that they missed good chances to score.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014, updated on 1 October 2014, measures the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. According to the index, Norway is the top-ranked country, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project, a partnership with Airbus, is building a satellite mega-constellation to provide global broadband internet. The network will begin with at least 600 spacecraft, which are being built using a new, low-cost, high-volume assembly line method, a significant change from traditional, expensive satellite manufacturing. The project requires the largest rocket campaign in history to launch the satellites. To mitigate space debris, OneWeb has committed to de-orbiting its satellites within two years and has included a feature allowing failed spacecraft to be captured and removed. While competitors like SpaceX and Boeing exist, OneWeb believes it has a first-mover advantage.

Mr. Swinney of the Scottish government stated that the UK government's spending review has placed "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland, arguing that the discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. He pledged to protect schools, hospitals, and the police from what he termed "the chancellor's austerity obsession." In response, the UK government said Scottish ministers would have £390m more in spending available next year. Labour's Jackie Baillie accused Mr. Swinney of "anti-austerity posturing" and called for a long-term budget.

Many people with severe disabilities and their carers find that ordinary accessible toilets are inadequate, as they may require assistance from multiple carers, a hoist, or a changing bench. "Changing Places" are larger, specially equipped toilets designed to meet these needs. There are 893 such toilets in the UK, but over a quarter of a million people are estimated to need them. Campaigners, including mother Lorna Fillingham, are calling for Changing Places to be made a compulsory requirement in building regulations for new, large public venues like shopping centres and cinemas. Currently, they are only a recommendation, which architects say is often ignored. While there are logistical and financial barriers to installation, particularly the 12-square-metre space requirement, the passage notes the positive impact they have, with Arsenal FC receiving a positive reaction for installing one and families being able to enjoy outings.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. The complaint is supported by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and other European unions. The organisations claim that franchisees are made to sign longer-than-average contracts and lease premises at above-market rates, which leads to higher prices and poorer consumer choice. McDonald's stated that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees and that its approach has been successful. The European Commission will study the submission.

A poster with the phrase #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood by the A2 as part of a social media campaign for 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign was started by Bangor Elim Church, where Joshua's father is on the pastoral staff, and the hashtag has since gone viral on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, reaching over 79,000 people worldwide. The poster was paid for by a mystery donor.

As part of a reorganisation of UK military buildings, Brecon Barracks is set to close. Conservative MP Chris Davies has condemned the decision, highlighting the barracks' history since 1805 and its importance to the town. He is launching a petition, concerned about the impact on local unemployment and military tourism. The barracks employs about 85 civilian staff and 90 military personnel, though jobs are not thought to be at risk. The reorganisation also includes creating a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, the closure of Cawdor Barracks in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. Labour's Shadow Defence Secretary, Nia Griffith, agreed with the principle of restructuring the estate but warned of the impact on people's livelihoods.

A House of Lords report on the UK fishing industry post-Brexit highlights several risks and opportunities. The industry, which largely supported leaving the EU to escape the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), hopes to regain control over UK waters. However, the report warns that because the industry is small, it risks being marginalised in wider Brexit negotiations. It also suggests that Britain may have to allow EU boats to fish in UK waters as a trade-off for continued tariff-free access to the EU market, where the UK exports most of its fish. The report raises concerns that leaving the EU could lead to four separate fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these risks, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic, believing Brexit offers more opportunities than threats and will give them "full control" of their economic zone.

Based on the passage, here is a concise summary:

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked documents revealing a massive US surveillance program. The documents allege that the National Security Agency (NSA), through a program called Prism, has "backdoor" access to the servers of nine major tech companies, including Google, Facebook, and Apple, allowing access to chat logs, stored data, and social media activity. US officials defended the surveillance as necessary for national security, while the tech companies denied involvement. The surveillance affects users globally, as data stored in the US is subject to American laws like the Patriot Act. Snowden stated he acted because he found the extent of the surveillance "horrifying."

OpenAI is a research venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. Its goal is to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity, unconstrained by financial obligations. This initiative comes amid warnings from figures like Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking about the potential threats of AI, though other experts view the risk as remote. OpenAI has a $1 billion pledge, but only a "tiny fraction" will be spent in the next few years. The venture's statement expresses that AI should be an "extension of individual human wills" and be distributed broadly and safely.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, carried the Olympic torch on June 26th. Since then, he has received thousands of Facebook friend requests, exceeding the 5,000 limit for a personal page. Despite a brain injury that initially took his speech, he now speaks unaided and spends 12 hours a day in rehab and the gym, in addition to raising money for military charities. His mother says he is "buoyed up" by the support. Facebook's guidance suggests he should consider having a page for public figures or use the subscribe feature.

In 2011, the poverty rate was 15%, representing 46.2 million Americans, and remained unchanged after three years of increases. Real median household income fell by 1.5%, and the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, saw its first annual increase since 1993, rising by 1.6%. The percentage of Americans without health insurance dropped from 16.3% to 15.7%. The poverty rate in 2010 was 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, who joined the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new deal with the club until 2019. A short-format specialist, he has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles described Buttler as "one of the most talented cricketers in the game" and a "great guy to have in the dressing room." After playing in the Indian Premier League with the Mumbai Indians, Buttler will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates (HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall) are moored in Portsmouth Harbour and are being sold. Bidders have registered interest, and a final decision is expected in the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority wants to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler. MP Penny Mordaunt supports giving UK recyclers a chance but also hopes one ship can be saved as a reef and diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to get the "best financial return for the taxpayer." No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. The frigates were powerful surface combatants with a crew of about 280.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced instability and international isolation due to racial and political tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. This has resulted in multiple coups, including in 1987, 2000, and 2006, which harmed the economy, particularly the tourism industry. These events led to Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009, though it was reinstated after holding elections in 2014. The unrest caused many Indo-Fijians to leave, making indigenous Fijians the majority. The population is largely segregated and resides mostly on the islands of Viti Levu and Vanua Levu. Fiji's diverse economy, which includes tourism, sugar, and mining, is hampered by deficits, making it a large recipient of foreign aid.

Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is "doing its best" to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timetable, blaming delays and a missed deadline on attacks by "terrorist groups" on weapon shipments. US officials expressed concern over the slow progress, with only 4% of the stockpile having left the country, while Russia suggested a new transfer deadline of March 1. Mr. Mekdad also denied the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims killed 246 people in five days. Additionally, the passage presents conflicting reports about Aleppo's central prison, with the Syrian government denying a rebel takeover that the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and other groups claim was successful.

The passage covers the shortlist for the 46th Booker Prize, which for the first time is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. Mukherjee's *The Lives Of Others* is the 5/2 favourite to win. The shortlist includes three British writers (Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith), two Americans (Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler), and an Australian (Richard Flanagan). Of the nominated books, Fowler's *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves* is the best-seller, and the shortlist announcement caused a sales spike for all the books. Professor David Brauner described the list as "weak," noting that Howard Jacobson's *J* is the strongest book but might not win. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall, and shortlisted authors each receive £2,500.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing to the Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Sun on Sunday newspaper wants to publish an account of his alleged extra-marital activities, including a three-way sexual encounter. PJS had previously obtained an injunction to prevent being named, but the Court of Appeal lifted it, arguing that details were already so widespread in other countries and online that confidentiality had "probably been lost." The Supreme Court will now hear arguments on whether to grant an appeal, and an interim injunction preventing PJS from being named will remain in place until the hearing concludes.

Fosse Park, which opened in 1989 near junction 21 of the M1, was bought in August for £345.5m. The new owners are now preparing plans to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units and common areas, as they believe the park has become "rather tired." According to Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, the new owners view the park as an investment they can improve and as the "gateway from Blaby into the city."

The release of a film in Malaysia was held for a "review" of its content after it emerged that it would feature a "gay moment." The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) has since approved the screening with a "P13 parental guidance classification" but with "a minor edit concerning a gay moment." Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia. A new release date has not been announced, and local cinema chains are offering refunds for advance tickets. The decision to review the film was criticized by the country's tourism minister and netizens.

Landlords who rent properties to more than three unrelated people in specific areas of Southampton need a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost £1,000. Many landlords are put off by the cost, despite facing a potential fine of £20,000, and the council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Tenants in these properties frequently express concerns about fear of eviction and poor maintenance. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Following an election almost two months ago, Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are trying to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil has agreed to facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government. A primary sticking point is water charges, which Fianna Fáil wants to remove immediately and Fine Gael wants to keep. One proposal is to create a commission to consider the future of Irish Water. The election results were Fine Gael with 50 seats and Fianna Fáil with 44, but no party was able to form a majority government, and a taoiseach has not yet been elected.

A fire broke out on The Sorrento ferry, which was travelling to Valencia. The blaze started on a car deck when the ship was 27km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon. Passengers were evacuated onto lifeboats and rescued by another ship, the Puglia, and are being taken back to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people were injured and taken to the hospital, with one seriously hurt. The cause of the fire is unclear, and the Balearic Islands port authority has stated that the ferry may sink. The Sorrento is owned by the Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione.

Following a record voter registration of 46.8 million people and the highest general election turnout since 1997, the Electoral Commission has addressed concerns raised by 38 MPs about people illegally voting twice. The commission identified a significant issue with duplicate applications, estimated to be between 30% and 70% in some areas, which creates administrative and financial burdens. This is caused by the online registration service and the 381 local electoral registers being separate, unconnected systems. To address this and reduce the risk of double voting, the watchdog recommends better joining up the registers and potentially adding a verification function. While noting that some people, like students, can be legally registered in two places, it is a criminal offence to vote twice in a general election. Labour warned against any changes that would make it harder for young people to register to vote.

Officials believe Lawrence Phillips, a 40-year-old former NFL player, killed himself in prison. In the 1990s, he was a star player at the University of Nebraska and played in the NFL for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, but had trouble on and off the field. He was serving a prison sentence of more than 30 years for convictions that included assault for driving his car into teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend. The day before his death, a judge had found enough evidence to try Phillips for the killing of his former cellmate. It is unclear how he took his own life.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and the mascot for the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to the rank of lance corporal for "good behaviour". The honour was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams at an event in Chester. He is the 30th mascot in a line that dates back to the mid-19th Century. As an official soldier, Lance Corporal Derby XXX has an army number, is paid for his rations, and takes holidays on the Chatsworth Estate. He has also met Prince William and helped switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne.

In a dramatic Europa League match, Liverpool achieved a 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time. The win was a significant comeback, as Liverpool were down 2-0 within nine minutes and later needed three goals in the final 33 minutes to advance. The victory is framed as a realization of manager Jurgen Klopp's philosophy to "turn doubters into believers," with Klopp invoking the spirit of the 2005 Istanbul Champions League final to inspire his team. The atmosphere at Anfield, fueled by Klopp and the supporters, was a key factor in unnerving Dortmund. As a result of the win, Liverpool moved into the semi-finals of the tournament, which provides a path to the Champions League.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee, Mr. Davis of the UK government stated he would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland updated on negotiations via monthly meetings, describing the meeting as "constructive and amicable." In contrast, Mr. Russell of the Scottish government said that while it was "good" the process was underway, the UK government needed to provide more transparency and clarity on its strategic intentions, particularly regarding the single market, which he called "essential for the economic prosperity of Scotland." The passage also notes that the Scottish government will seek to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court appeal over how Article 50 will be triggered.

A study led by Professor Kevin Sinclair at the University of Nottingham is monitoring a flock of 13 cloned sheep, four of which are identical sisters to Dolly the sheep. The research aims to determine if cloned animals age normally and are healthy, addressing concerns that arose after the original Dolly developed osteoarthritis and died at the relatively young age of six-and-a-half. The core concern is that the cloning process might transfer "age-memory" from the adult cell's DNA, causing the clone to age prematurely. To investigate this, the sheep are undergoing extensive tests, including X-rays and fMRI scans, focusing on age-related conditions like osteoarthritis, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease. The sheep, approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, appear to be in good health.

The unbeaten 4-7 favourite, Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters on very soft ground. This was the fifth Musidora win for both Gosden and Dettori. Shutter Speed will next go to Chantilly, not the Oaks at Epsom, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are contenders. In another race, Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes. Gosden is also concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will walk the course before deciding if he runs.

The pound sterling experienced volatility, falling against the dollar, euro, and Japanese yen due to investor uncertainty surrounding the upcoming EU referendum. This uncertainty was fueled by polls showing the "Leave" camp ahead and a drop in the implied probability of a "Remain" vote. The "volatility index" reached levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The economic worries also led to falls in Asian stock markets, with Japan's Nikkei index closing down 3.5%, and London's FTSE 100 ending the day 1.1% lower. The Leave campaign argued that the pound had only retreated to March levels and that a weaker pound would be good for UK exporters. Analysts noted that hedge funds were short-selling sterling, betting on its value sinking further.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off spots. Their losing run has been extended to three games following a defeat to Barrow, who are now unbeaten in nine league games. According to Cowley, the match was tough due to a "six or seven-hour journey" and conceding a goal after five minutes. He described what his part-time team has done so far as "nothing short of remarkable" and said they will embrace their "toughest challenge to date."

From April 2015, responsibility for most planning decisions in Northern Ireland will shift from the Planning Service to local councils, meaning elected politicians will make the final decisions. Proponents, like Michael Corr of PLACE, view this as a "huge opportunity" to democratise the planning system and allow councils to develop their own communities. However, critics such as Friends of the Earth express concern, warning of potential discrimination similar to that seen in the 1960s and citing "close relationships between developers and political parties". They argue that a strictly enforced code of conduct and transparency regarding political donations will be necessary to ensure the system is fair. The decision on when to make political donations more transparent rests with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times in Winchburgh, resulting in the amputation of her left back leg. The Scottish SPCA is using the incident to call for the licensing of airguns. Last year, the Scottish government held a consultation on this, but 87% of respondents opposed the plan. The Scottish SPCA is asking anyone with information about the shooting to contact them.

Christian Benteke has signed for Liverpool on a "long-term contract," becoming the club's second most expensive signing after they triggered a release clause in his Aston Villa contract. The 24-year-old Belgium international, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, was signed to address Liverpool's lack of goals from the previous season. Benteke is Liverpool's seventh summer signing and stated he joined "to win trophies." He joins other new forwards Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino.

A study commissioned by the charity Tablets for Schools, which surveyed 671 schools, found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. Despite this, tablet use is widespread and growing, present in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with the total number expected to nearly double to 900,000 by 2016. While researchers cannot definitively link tablets to improved results, head teachers reported positive impacts like increased motivation and family involvement. The study also noted that many pupils take devices to bed for social media, and a quarter of secondary pupils with their own tablet described themselves as internet "addicts." A separate study found that touch-screen computers were particularly useful for helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read.

The "Growing Up in the City" exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool displays 25 photographs that capture the life of children in the city from the 1880s to the 1990s. The images provide a social history, showing how childhood has changed, including children at play and those who had to work. Examples include an 1887 portrait of the wealthy Rollo children in fancy dress and a c. 1900 portrait of a young maid. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones from the National Museums Liverpool's collections and runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join a National League rival. He is a former player for Aldershot and Exeter. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, has also joined the Gulls, with his move being subject to international clearance. He has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a "leader-type" and Keating as "young" and "incredibly hungry." The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone.

Bolivia has enacted a new law that permits 12-year-olds to be contracted for work with parental authorisation. Signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, the legislation is intended to reflect the needs of Bolivia as one of South America's poorest countries. The law also sets harsher punishments for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The International Labour Organisation (ILO), which allows a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, is studying the new legislation to determine if it breaches international regulations. According to UNICEF, over 500,000 children already work in Bolivia.

After falling ill at home with chest aches, nausea, and fever, 50-year-old Rosie O'Donnell looked up "women's heart attack symptoms" online and took aspirin. The following day, a cardiologist inserted a stent into her artery, which was 99% blocked. The heart attack was a type known as the "widow maker." Although she did not call emergency services, she now advises women to know the symptoms and call 911.

Che Labastide-Wellington was stabbed in an alleyway in Kenton at about 00:30 GMT on a Saturday and was pronounced dead an hour later. He had been at a party but was not involved in an earlier fight when a group of youths tried to gain entry; police believe he was targeted later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. A 21-year-old man and two boys (aged 15 and 16) have been arrested on suspicion of murder, and a 14-year-old has been arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Based on the passage, Denmark addressed its poor cancer survival statistics by reorganizing its patient diagnosis system, which a team from Wales visited to study. The problem was long waiting times for diagnosis, especially for patients with vague or non-obvious symptoms.

The new Danish model has three routes:
1.  A fast-track route for patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers.
2.  Diagnosis centres for patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, where they receive a range of tests and scans quickly.
3.  "Yes-no" centres for patients with minor symptoms, offering a simple test or scan to quickly identify or rule out serious issues.

This new approach has resulted in better organization, improved cancer survival rates, and is helping Denmark catch up with other European countries without "flooding of the system."

Following the UK government's decision to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), Powys council has won a competitive bid to take over the regulation of estate agents. Powys will receive £170,000 a year to deliver the service, which will have the power to issue warning and banning orders against agents who act dishonestly or breach estate agent laws. Consumers will continue to complain to their local authority trading standards, who will then refer cases to Powys if they suspect a breach of the Estate Agents Act. The new team will be led by James Munro.

Based on a Nuffield Trust review, the management body NHS Employers has approved a plan to train health staff, such as nurses, to perform a wider range of tasks. This is intended to help cover doctor shortages and cope with the rising number of patients, as well as adapt to the changing nature of care which now focuses more on long-term conditions. However, unions have warned against using this as a "quick fix." The British Medical Association stated that this should not come at the expense of doctors' training or expertise, and Unison raised concerns about the lack of funding for training courses, cautioning that it must not be a "cheap fix" for staff shortages. The Nuffield Trust acknowledged that money would need to be set aside for the plan to happen.

At 03:00 GMT, a crash on the Lower Bristol Road in Bath caused Avon and Somerset Police to close the A36. The road closure resulted in disruption and delays for commuters and bus services during rush hour and was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations into the collision are underway. First bus services were affected, with the company's managing director hoping for a full service to be running by the evening commute and thanking the public and staff.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) are in a dispute over the environmental impact of a proposed £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon. NRW estimates the lagoon would kill 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually, a figure based on what it calls the "best available evidence." TLP disputes this, claiming the figures have no "clear scientific basis," are "grossly misleading," and that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's own modelling estimates a "worst case scenario" of the lagoon killing 2% of all fish species. The UK government is reviewing the project's viability, while the Welsh Government is supportive but seeks clarity. NRW stated it strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism, had shared its methodology and data over a year-and-a-half, and has the "utmost confidence" in its evidence.

Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland, which will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). The body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, aims to provide strategic leadership for marketing activities. The agri-food industry is described as "hugely important," with almost 100,000 jobs. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement as a "positive step" to address the need for better marketing coordination, but noted the plans could have "implications for the work of other organisations," including her own department.

On Saturday afternoon, the public is invited to plant trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. The event, organised by the Woodland Trust, is part of a four-year project to create four new woods across the UK to commemorate the millions who died in WW1. The aim at Brackfield Wood is to plant 40,000 native trees as a tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who died in the conflict. The charity is providing saplings and advises volunteers to wear appropriate footwear. The finished wood is intended to be a place for wildlife to thrive and for people to reflect.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for the book *Someone Else's Skin*, a thriller about domestic violence and honour crime featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. The award was presented at the annual crime writing festival in Harrogate. At the same event, US author Sara Paretsky, creator of the detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career and for setting up Sisters In Crime, an organisation that supports female crime writers.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, will rejoin Worcestershire for the next summer season. His previous time with the county in 2016 was cut short when he broke his finger in his second game, which director of cricket Steve Rhodes called a "massive blow" to the team's hopes. Santner will rejoin the team after the ICC Trophy in June, stating he has "unfinished business" and wants to "make up for lost time." In August, Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

In 2008, Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding car with stolen license plates while hailing a taxi in Kiev. A UK coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating she was satisfied "beyond reasonable doubt" that he was unlawfully killed. At the time of the incident, his wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant. Pring's family believes he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run, and the inquest heard that Ziuzina tried to claim his assets days after his death, sold his property, and was having an affair. A Ukrainian murder inquiry was launched in 2011 but is described as active but "not actively pursued".

Charlie, a boy from Merseyside who has been ill since age three, needs to fly to Seattle for experimental T-Cell Therapy that is unavailable in the UK. This is required after a third relapse and a previously failed transplant. An anonymous donor has paid for the treatment at Seattle Children's Hospital. His parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns, were informed via an email from the hospital and expressed that they were "ecstatic," "overwhelmed," and "extremely grateful." Charlie now has financial clearance, and the treatment will start as soon as possible.

Following the theft of celebrity photos from iCloud, Apple has implemented a two-step verification system for its backup service. This security feature is an opt-in choice that requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device when logging in from a new device. This closes a loophole that allowed third-party software to download complete data backups. A 14-character recovery key is provided to regain access if a trusted device is lost, though concerns were raised that this key could be lost or stolen. One expert suggested that this two-factor authentication should be the default setting. Additionally, Apple will now send an email notification to account holders whenever a backup download is initiated.

A deal is being discussed which could see Wright buy 20% of the Billericay football club and become a director, though the "finer points" have not yet been released. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week, and they have signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Billericay are currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright was a runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011 and has played non-league football for several clubs.

Following a BBC investigation into working practices at a Derbyshire company's warehouse, Mr. Ashley has been asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers. Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, has given Mr. Ashley until 21 March to agree to attend a public meeting in Westminster. Mr. Ashley has not accepted any of the dates offered. The letter warns that if he fails to agree, the committee may take the matter further, including seeking the support of the House of Commons for a complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has not commented to the BBC.

A report titled "Putin. War," initiated by the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and completed by his colleagues, argues that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. Based on previously reported facts, the report claims that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in all major victories for pro-Russian rebels and that Russian generals, not separatists, directed the main battles. It calculates Russian spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles and states that "volunteer" soldiers were paid salaries. This contradicts Russia's official position that any Russians fighting in Ukraine are "volunteers." The report's authors face challenges in publishing and distribution, with an initial print run of only 2,000 copies. It is noted that previous reports by Nemtsov failed to galvanise protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem found that the 34-year-old died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, complained that he was not shown the Article 50 letter before it was published, calling it "unacceptable" and a "lack of respect." In response, Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns stated that the letter's contents had been discussed for months. The letter itself, written by Mrs. May, promised to consult on which powers returning from the EU should be devolved to Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, with the expectation of a "significant increase in the decision-making power" for each. However, it is currently a "mystery" which specific powers will be devolved and whether money will follow them, as Alun Cairns would not answer those questions.

On Friday night in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry, two cars were damaged. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin described the incident as "mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community." According to a PSNI Facebook post, police were attacked while "carrying out duties" and appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr. Charney, the founder of a company, was ousted due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. In response to Mr. Charney's defamation lawsuit, the company's board filed court documents containing evidence of his illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, stating he violated sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board does not expect him to return to the firm. Mr. Charney's lawyer claims these statements are false and an invasion of privacy. Additionally, the company, American Apparel, was granted a restraining order preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company or trying to remove board members.

Great Britain is set to play Greece at the Copper Box in what will be their only home game before FIBA EuroBasket 2017. In a previous match, Greece defeated Great Britain 92-64, but three members of the Greek team will be missing for this game. After playing Greece, the British team will travel to a tournament in Poland for their last warm-up games. The game will be available to watch on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30-19:30 BST.

A BBC reporter, covering the launch of the first iPhone, managed to borrow the device from Apple's marketing chief, Phil Schiller, for a news report. The report drew criticism from some viewers for giving "undue prominence" to a product launch. The reporter defended the coverage by comparing the iPhone's potential impact to that of the Model T Ford. He now believes that comparison was not "outlandish," as the smartphone became the "key transformative technology of the last decade," disrupting industries such as photography. The author attributes the iPhone's success to its attractive user interface, which made people want to do more than just talk and text on their phones, and he views the launch as the beginning of the "mobile connected era."

Tests confirmed that several cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting a toxic substance. Five cats have died in recent weeks, including a seven-month-old named Meereen who was confirmed to have consumed antifreeze. The RSPCA stated it is unclear whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is appealing for residents to ensure chemicals and pesticides are stored safely and that any antifreeze spills are cleaned up.

Despite the Syriza government preparing to implement more austerity measures for a new €86bn bailout, there are no protests on the streets of Athens, and tourism is booming. The government's leader, Alexis Tsipras, remains popular despite accepting terms he previously rejected. This change is attributed to Greece's "near-death experience" in July, which involved bank closures and economic collapse, leading to the belief that "there is no alternative." The country is now suffering from a "vicious economic squeeze" and monetary austerity, as banks have no money to lend. The passage concludes that for the bailout to lead to a genuine recovery, creditors in Brussels and Berlin must offer significant debt forgiveness.

Ross Kemp is making a "brief return" to EastEnders to reprise his role as Grant Mitchell. He is returning for the final episodes of Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, who is his mother and is being killed off from cancer. The return will reunite the Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil, with their mother for the last time. Kemp last played the character in 2006, and Peggy's death from the disease will be screened in the spring.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. He was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. When police informed Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, of her death, they immediately knew Dhillon was responsible. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring her daughter that she would be alright and for dismissing her other daughter's warning that Dhillon would kill her. The parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking.

The French firm EDF approved its £18bn financing for the Hinkley Point nuclear project in Somerset, but the UK government then announced it would conduct a further review before giving its final approval, postponing the decision until the autumn. One-third of the project's cost is being provided by Chinese investors. The project has faced criticism over environmental damage, potential escalating costs, and the involvement of foreign governments. An EDF board member and its finance director have resigned over the project's financial risks. Hinkley Point C is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity, and supporters have urged the government to make a quick decision to avoid future energy supply problems.

A new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers are concerned that this will add "conflict and complexity" to proceedings. Although guidance on the form states it is "not normally necessary" to name the third party, lawyers believe the direct question is an "invitation" that people will find difficult to refuse. The Ministry of Justice has stated there is "no obligation" to name anyone. If a person is named, they become part of the court case, which can lead to delays and increased costs.

There is a belief that ministers are placing too much emphasis on the environment at the expense of timber production. Britain is the world's third-largest wood importer, and the forestry industry is worth over £450m a year to the Welsh economy. Confor, an industry body, warns that 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need replanting. There is a conflict with environmental policy, which has favoured native, broadleaf trees and better public access, while conservationists claim commercial forests are bad for wildlife. The Welsh government wants a balance between environmental, economic, and social factors. However, Confor states the system for creating new woodland is too bureaucratic and that planting rates are far below targets, with only 90 hectares planted last year against a required 20,000 hectares a year. There is a "huge market" for timber, and saw millers would increase production if more was available.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in an incident on Bank Street in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School, at about 16:40. Emergency crews attended the scene, and the boy was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to British veterans of the Arctic Convoys for their role in resupplying the Soviet Union during World War II. The convoys faced constant threats from German attacks and severe weather, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The Russian embassy stated the convoys were a "material expression of our wartime alliance" that helped them defeat the Germans. The presentation of the medals was initially blocked by the UK Foreign Office due to rules on foreign medals but an "exception" was later made. The British Government had created its own Arctic Star medal for the veterans in 2012.

Based on the passage, a report by HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant issues with the unpaid work scheme for offenders, including delays in starting work and a lack of consequences for non-attendance. In one case, an offender completed only 16 hours in 17 months. The report, which made 15 recommendations, noted that while some work was high-quality and some offenders viewed their sentence positively, much of the scheme was "not good enough" and a "wasted opportunity." The Chief Inspector of Probation called for "urgent remedial action." The Ministry of Justice accepted all the report's recommendations and stated it was taking action to ensure offenders attend their work and face consequences if they do not.

A comedian, identified as Brand, has been called a "hypocrite" by a paper for campaigning for an economic and political "revolution" to help the poor while living in a luxury home. When questioned about his own rent by a TV reporter at a housing protest, Brand called the journalist "a snide" and walked off. In response to the paper's accusations, he has been tweeting with the hashtag #TheSunLogic. Brand has previously addressed the hypocrisy charge by acknowledging his wealth but arguing that personal attacks distract from the real issues of economic disparity and ecological disaster. He believes that systemic change is required, and without it, individual gestures like sharing wealth are "futile." He suggests the hypocrisy accusation is used to avoid discussing inequality and that it is a problem that can be dealt with "incrementally."

Dr. J. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur who turned the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, which caused him to be vilified by the scientific community but also sped up the process. His experience as a hospital orderly in the Vietnam War gave him a sense of urgency. He developed a breakthrough method for gene sequencing by focusing on messenger RNA, which was criticized by figures like James Watson. This criticism and a lack of public funding led him to leave the NIH to set up private institutes.

His major achievements include publishing the first complete genome of a free-living organism (Haemophilus influenzae) in 1995, forming Celera Genomics in 1998 to crack the human genetic code, and creating a synthetic life form called Synthia. He has also sailed the oceans on his yacht to collect and sequence marine microbes. Dr. Venter believes synthetic microbes could create a new industrial revolution, helping to reduce reliance on oil and capture carbon dioxide.

Based on a survey of about 1,000 parents, researchers found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school they had not previously tried at home. Half of the parents said their children had subsequently asked for those foods to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The research was commissioned by England's School Food Trust. About four in ten primary school children in England eat school lunches, which now have to comply with strict nutritional guidelines.

Álvaro Morata, a 23-year-old striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus from Real Madrid in 2014. His transfer included a buy-back option for Real for a fee of up to 30m euros (£23m). Previously a reported target for Arsenal and Chelsea, Morata scored 27 goals for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in consecutive Champions League finals: as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 2015 defeat. Morata came through the ranks at Real, making his debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the club.

The 30-year-old, Wilson, has been without a team since being released in May. He rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, making 51 appearances in his second spell at the club. He had previously spent four seasons with Forest and has also had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

A British supermarket giant is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. Fresh & Easy has been unprofitable since opening in 2007. As part of the deal, 4,000 of the 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business, while 50 of the 200 stores will be closed. The disposal will cost Tesco £150m, which includes an £80m loan to the new business. Tesco retains the option to buy a stake in the new business if it becomes profitable.
An individual experienced racial abuse, which he overcame. After briefly considering representing France, he is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Based on the research presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting, the ice fields in the French Alps decreased from approximately 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s, representing an average loss of 26% over 40 years. This new inventory, created by Marie Gardent and colleagues, assessed roughly 600 glaciers using maps, satellite imagery, and manual inspection. The retreat has not been uniform; the greatest losses have occurred in the southern sectors, such as the Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs, which is attributed to lower mountain elevations and different climatic conditions compared to the north. These findings mirror reports of glacier retreat in other parts of the Alps.

The Scottish women's football team has won all five of its qualifiers and a victory against Iceland would all but secure their place in the finals. Player Lisa Evans describes the desperation to qualify after previous play-off losses, calling another failure "devastating" and "heartbreak." Iceland is also unbeaten, and the two matches between the teams will likely decide the group winner. Scotland is in a strong position to qualify automatically, even as a runner-up. Evans, one of 12 players in the squad who play for clubs outside Scotland, believes that the experience gained in top foreign leagues benefits the national team by adding different playing styles and cultures.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint of online harassment from a woman in south London, which she alleged took place over a two-year period. Mr. Campbell, a blogger for Wings Over Scotland, was released on bail until mid-September. He stated that the allegations relate entirely to some tweets which he insisted were not threatening and are still publicly visible. He accused the media of using "innuendo" to encourage speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating an allegation of online harassment.

Peta (People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals) wants to replace the Skegness mascot, the Jolly Fisherman, with a fish mascot and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," arguing the current mascot "evokes images of cruelty to animals." The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway with the slogan "Skegness is so bracing." The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, stated that while the suggestion is welcome, he does not believe there is much support for the change, describing the current mascot as "happy and friendly."

Georgia initially led with an early try from Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland dominated the first half with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg. At one point before the break, Scotland had 91% possession. In the second half, Hamish Watson scored for Scotland before Lobzhanidze scored a second try for Georgia following a powerful scrum. Stuart Hogg then scored his second try to finish the match. The game also saw yellow cards for Georgia's Kote Mikautadze and Scotland's Moray Low. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, was pleased with the first half and the team's pragmatic approach.

Widnes defeated Castleford after leading 14-6 at half-time. Tries for Widnes were scored by Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van (2), Chris Bridge, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. For Castleford, Paddy Flynn scored a hat-trick against his parent club, with Larne Patrick and Luke Gale also scoring tries. Widnes's victory looked assured at 38-12, but three Castleford tries in four minutes created a "nervy finish." This was the Tigers' fourth consecutive home league defeat. As a result, Widnes moved up to seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, has been released from the US facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after a review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat." He had been held since 2002 after his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies, stating he was in the region to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. Under the terms of his release, he will spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. His release, the first since May, brings the total number of inmates at the facility down to 148.

The song "PPAP" (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen) was performed by DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character played by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka. The minute-long song went viral due to its addictive beat, silly lyrics, and simple dance routine. First uploaded to YouTube, it spread quickly on Facebook, where one video by 9GAG surpassed 44 million views. Reactions were mixed, with some users finding it catchy and amusing, while others found it irritating. Piko-Taro has been dubbed the "next Psy," and the song has inspired hundreds of tribute videos and covers. At the time of writing, the song had been widely picked up internationally but had not been covered by many mainstream Japanese news sites or trended on Japanese social media.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One. Commemorations included an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner attended by thousands, a parade with up to 400 people, a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph, and a service at Westminster Abbey. The first Anzac Day was commemorated in 1916, a year after the Anzac landings at Gallipoli, an eight-month campaign in Turkey. The services are an important event for New Zealanders and Australians to honour the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old who was capped twice for Scotland in 2008, has joined St Mirren and could make his debut against Alloa on Saturday. He joined Premiership Well in July and scored nine goals at Dundee last season. With almost 400 senior club appearances, his previous teams include Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. Clarkson states he is fit and ready to play. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship.

The turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Following the sale, guarantees were given that all current agreements, including the workers' pension scheme, will be honoured. The new owner's plan is to restore the business to profitability through greater investment, cost savings, and by using spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

A council scrutiny meeting was held to discuss problems with a new chain ferry. Since its launch on 14 May, the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended due to "training issues," and has damaged cars. A local shopkeeper reported a loss of almost six months of trade. In response, Council leader Dave Stewart said the crossing would be free until 2 July and that a review of the project had been ordered. Transport councillor Ian Ward stated that electrical problems had been rectified, ramp extensions were authorized to address vehicle damage, and groundings were a "seamanship" issue that had been resolved. He added that compensation for businesses was "up for discussion."

A House of Lords report examines the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. While many in the industry supported leaving the EU to escape the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and regain control of UK waters, the report warns that the industry may be a low priority in negotiations as it only accounts for half of one percent of GDP. It also cautions that Britain may have to allow EU boats to fish in UK waters as a trade-off for continued access to the EU market, where the majority of UK fish are sold. The report suggests retaining some elements of the CFP, such as basing quotas on scientific advice, and notes that leaving the CFP could result in four different fisheries management regimes for England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland. Despite these warnings, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the opportunities Brexit will bring.

Timothy Geaney, who admitted to taking or permitting indecent images of young boys to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014, was given a community payback order and placed on the sex offenders register. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was removed from the teaching profession's register. The panel found his conduct "fundamentally incompatible" with being a teacher, noted the offending took place over a lengthy period, and concluded there was a strong likelihood of it recurring. Geaney was found unfit to teach and is prohibited from applying to re-register for two years.

A fire on 2 March at a site in Duncan Street, operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, caused train and travel delays. Following the fire, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste and has now decided to revoke its environmental permit, effective 7 August, subject to appeal. The company must still remove all waste from the site. The fire service had visited the site nine times in the last year and stated the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, but had raised concerns to the EA in February. The cause of the fire is undetermined.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that Syria is "doing its best" to destroy its chemical weapons but missed a deadline due to attacks on shipments by "terrorist groups." The US expressed concern over the delay, with only 4% of the 1,300-tonne stockpile having been removed, while Russia set a new deadline of March 1st. Mr. Mekdad denied that the government targets civilians with barrel bombs in Aleppo, calling US condemnation "absolutely unacceptable," despite reports from activist groups of hundreds of civilian casualties. There are also conflicting reports regarding Aleppo's central prison, with rebel groups claiming to have seized it and freed detainees, while Syrian state media insists the attack was thwarted.

England beat Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series in what was their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, as well as taking four catches and one wicket. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, while Pakistan were bowled out for 198 and 234. Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed his disappointment, stating the team was "short of confidence" and that "shot selection really cost us." The third Test is scheduled for 3 August at Edgbaston.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners, their friends, and families, which will be used to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will look at factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Mario Kreft, the chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review's aims but expressed disappointment that the advisory panel does not include a provider expert, such as someone who has lived in, worked in, managed, or owned a care home.

Paul Sheerin, 39, a former Dons midfielder, has been appointed to a position at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin had been the player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, where he led the team to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title in 2011. His playing career included time at several Scottish clubs, Östersunds in Sweden, and a Scotland Under-21 cap. Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two after the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's chief executive stated that manager Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a "comprehensive process" and that the Arbroath chairman was cooperative with Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth. The club wants to appoint a new manager soon, with Paul Clement as the first choice. Curtis expressed concern that if Swansea were relegated to the Championship, it would be "tough to get back." He believes the club has "lost our way" since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 due to frequent management changes, diluting the "Swansea Way." However, Curtis thinks the current squad is good enough to stay up and that new players are shown a documentary about the club's history to understand the importance of avoiding relegation.

Dr. J. Craig Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur who turned the mapping of the human genome into a competitive race, which sped up the process but also caused him to be vilified by the scientific community. His sense of urgency was inspired by his time as a naval orderly in the Vietnam War. Venter developed a breakthrough for rapidly sequencing genes and, after facing criticism, left the public sector to form private institutes. In 1995, he sequenced the first complete genome of a free-living organism. In 1998, his company, Celera Genomics, challenged the public project to sequence the human genome, with both publishing their results in 2001. Venter later created the first synthetic life form, an organism called Synthia, and has also undertaken a project to sequence the genomes of marine microbes. He believes synthetic microbes could lead to a "new industrial revolution" by helping to reduce reliance on oil and capturing carbon dioxide.

A report from the Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short compared to other European countries. The study found that since 2010, over half of apprenticeships have been below level three (A-level equivalent), and three-quarters have been for people over 25. In England, only 20% of employers offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany. The report calls for the creation of up to 300,000 new apprenticeships annually, with the majority being at level three or higher. The Association of Colleges notes that some respected level two apprenticeships should be preserved, while the Department for Education states that it is already reforming apprenticeships to "drive up standards."

The Briton, Storey, won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Anna Harkowska of Poland. At 37 years old, Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze) and 21 world titles across both cycling and swimming. She began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005. She is targeting further success at the next Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro and can win a 17th title in Saturday's road race.

Hereford United, also known as "the Bulls," has been expelled from the Football Conference due to financial issues. The club failed to meet a final deadline of 12 June to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors, which included former manager Martin Foyle, players, and staff. The Conference had previously extended the payment deadline three times. As a result of the expulsion, Chester has been reinstated into the Conference Premier. The club's financial problems have been exacerbated by falling attendance since their relegation from the Football League in 2012. An offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy the club for £1 and clear its debts was not the preferred option for the chairman prior to a takeover by London businessman Tommy Agombar.

The 30-year-old former Manchester City player, Milner, won 61 caps for England following his senior debut in 2009. He was a squad member for two World Cups and two European Championships, playing three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner is also the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 win against Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, died at his home in Cambridge after an illness. In 1973, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), which he directed for about 30 years, recording over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah was named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood also held positions as artistic director for the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and was a professor at the University of Cambridge, Harvard University, and Cornell University. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to follow at a later date.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping. His parents requested a place for him at a special school but were told in September that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full to capacity. The boy's mother, who had to give up her job to care for him, is concerned about her son feeling isolated and worries that other families will face the same situation due to the over-subscribed system. The family has recently been told that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school, and they hope their son can start there in the next few weeks. The Education Authority would not comment on the individual case but stated it is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland to assist with placements from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has made a takeover bid for the Newport Gwent Dragons and sees their shared ground, Rodney Parade, "as a rugby venue." Newport County football club has a lease to use the ground until 2023, which they expect to be honoured. The WRU's plan to install an artificial surface is against Football League rules. According to Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey, both Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU's takeover will be put to a shareholder vote on Tuesday, 9 May. On the pitch, Newport County are two points clear of relegation from League Two with two games remaining.

The narrator, a former child soldier who was kidnapped at 15 by RUF rebels during the civil war, describes his journey of rehabilitation and his work fighting the Ebola virus. After escaping the rebels, he was helped by a preacher named Richard Cole, who encouraged him to rebuild his life and contribute to the nation. When the Ebola crisis began, the narrator's organization educated over 10,000 people about the virus, provided food and support to 11,000 people, and helped establish an Ebola treatment unit. He now regrets his past and is focused on investing in young people to build a better future.

A collection of 80,000 Wedgwood works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, and other items was saved from being auctioned to pay the firm's pension debt. A public fundraising campaign, led by The Art Fund, hit its target in one month. The collection will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and then loaned to the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, where it will remain on display.

A deal is being discussed for Mark Wright to buy 20% of Billericay football club and become a club director, though the "finer points" have not been released. The club, which is eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 a week. The team has also signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Wright is a former non-league footballer and was the runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011.

Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, announced he would extend his term by one year, rather than leaving in 2018 as originally planned or staying until 2021. The decision was described as "entirely personal" and the "clincher" was his family's circumstances. In 2018, one of his daughters will be finishing her A-levels and another her GCSEs, and his family planned to return to Canada. Professionally, Carney felt it would be difficult to leave in the middle of Brexit negotiations, so the one-year extension ensures the Article 50 process should be complete upon his departure. The passage dismisses political pressure or criticism of the Bank's economic forecasts as factors in his decision.

The football match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool after 12 minutes, and Kurtis Guthrie equalised for Colchester from a corner. Both teams had chances to win the game, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred heading wide and Colchester's Kurtis Guthrie heading against the bar. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle in injury time.

The "Healthy Me" programme, developed by the charity Action Mental Health, is designed to help P6 and P7 pupils in Northern Ireland cope with the stress of the transfer test and the transition to secondary school. The programme uses interactive workshops to teach children about emotional wellbeing, encourage them to seek help, and identify sources of support. The workshops also provide teachers with basic training. Following a pilot in five schools, the charity hopes to roll the programme out across Northern Ireland.

The disused Fawley power station chimney is set to become an attraction, which would be the tallest of its kind south of London's Shard. It is the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside that will also feature a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The oil-fired power station was commissioned in 1971, closed in 2013, and was capable of powering one million homes. The site was sold to the developers in 2016, with a planning application due later in the year and building potentially starting in 2018. A representative for the developer said they would be "mad to knock the chimney down" as it is their "signature piece of infrastructure."

At the Hong Kong championships, a 23-year-old cyclist named Latham won a bronze medal for Great Britain (GB) in the men's scratch race. This was GB's second medal, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. In other events, the GB men's team pursuit lost the bronze medal match to Italy, and the women's team pursuit finished fifth. Additionally, Joe Truman was eliminated from the men's keirin semi-final, and Katy Marchant was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.

Ross Kemp, who plays Grant Mitchell, is making a "brief return" to EastEnders for the final episodes of Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Kemp last played the role in 2006. Peggy's character has returned to Albert Square to tell her son Phil that her cancer has returned, and she will be killed off in the spring. Kemp, a close friend of Windsor's, said he felt it was right for the Mitchell brothers to be reunited with their mother for the last time. His return will bring the Mitchell family back together.

Sadio Mane scored two goals in 138 seconds, leading to a defeat for second-placed Spurs at Anfield. Manager Pochettino stated it is "very difficult to fight for the Premier League" with a "lack of desire" and that his team was "not ready to fight." He added that if Chelsea extends their lead to 12 points, it would be a "big problem." The loss highlighted Spurs' poor away form, having won just once in their past 17 away meetings with other top-six sides. Pundit Danny Murphy expressed surprise at the performance, noting Spurs used a back four instead of their usual back three against big sides and that there is a "different mindset" when they play away from home.

Based on the text provided, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Saturday's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP, which won eight governorships, lost for the first time in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna and was relegated to a regional party with wins mostly in the south-east. The APC's leader, Muhammadu Buhari, is the president-elect. A key concern for the incoming government is that the APC failed to win any of the five oil-producing states. The result in Taraba is still outstanding, and the election in Imo was declared inconclusive.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will offer an app that uses augmented reality.
