Visitors can use their phones and tablets to scan items like signs and posters to access online material, including videos and band interviews. The app is intended as an extra feature for festival-goers and to allow people worldwide to interact with the event. The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean are among the festival's acts.

Following an Ofsted investigation into an alleged hardline Muslim takeover plot, Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated "inadequate," will have their funding agreements terminated. The Park View Educational Trust stated it may be removed from running the schools. Two other inadequate-rated schools, Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, were warned they could lose funding if concerns were not addressed.

Education minister Lord Nash sent letters outlining the actions, citing "deep concerns" and a failure to promote pupils' "spiritual, moral, social and cultural development." Demands for Oldknow and Golden Hillock included ending the segregation of boys and girls and the "less favourable" treatment of non-Muslims.

Ofsted's chief described a "culture of fear and intimidation," and the report on Park View noted inadequate safeguards against extremism, including allowing an unvetted speaker with known extremist views. An anonymous head teacher described feeling undermined by parents. While the schools plan to challenge the reports, some parents have criticized Ofsted's findings as biased.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was sentenced to five years in jail for allegedly plotting to topple the government in Tehran. She was arrested at Tehran Airport in April with her two-year-old daughter, Gabriella, and has spent time in solitary confinement. An appeal against her sentence is being held in secret. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, believes she is being used as a bargaining chip and has criticized the UK government for a lack of action. The couple's daughter has had her passport confiscated and is being cared for by her grandparents in Iran. Amnesty International UK considers Mrs. Zaghari-Ratcliffe a "prisoner of conscience."

Eye specialist Honey Rose is on trial for gross negligence manslaughter following the death of Vincent "Vinnie" Barker in July 2012. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court alleges that Ms. Rose's conduct was "criminal" because she failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during a routine eye test five months before his death. The court heard that a build-up of fluid in his brain led to his death, which the prosecution claims was preventable. Ms. Rose denies the charge.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man from an adult website and filming them between September 2013 and September 2014. He also sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014. After denying the charges, he was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court, and the case was moved to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and assessed as a "moderate risk" of sexual re-offending. The victim told the trial she felt "blackmailed."

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Afghanistan defeated Ireland by scoring 171-4 to beat Ireland's total of 165-5. For Ireland, Stuart Thompson scored 56, Gary Wilson made 41 not out, and William Porterfield contributed 39. For Afghanistan, Samiullah Shenwari scored 56 and Mohammad Shahzad hit 47, helping their team to victory with two overs to spare. The two sides will play again in a second T20 at the same location on Friday. Irish paceman Boyd Rankin missed the match due to a back problem.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for striker Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of that fee. A judge in Spain is investigating the transfer after allegations that the actual cost was far greater than the amount Barcelona initially stated. Following these accusations, club president Sandro Rosell resigned and is also being investigated. While Barcelona insists they have not committed any offence and denies any tax-related crime, they have made a "complimentary tax declaration" of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover "eventual interpretations" of the contracts. Including all fees, wages, and this tax payment, Neymar will have cost the club £106.8m. It is not yet confirmed if the case will be dropped after this payment.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were discovered on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK detectives have completed a review of the Thai police investigation into their murders and will now return to the UK to compile a report for the families. Two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are being held as suspects and are charged with conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery. Thai police state the suspects confessed and that their DNA matched samples found on Ms. Witheridge, but there are reports the confessions were withdrawn. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the Thai investigation, specifically regarding the verification of DNA and allegations of the suspects' mistreatment. Post-mortem examinations found Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Miss Witheridge died from head wounds.

Virtual Reality (VR) is being used in various fields beyond entertainment. Charities like the National Autistic Society and Alzheimer's Research UK have created VR films to help the public understand these conditions by simulating the experience of living with them. In retail, Ikea has used a VR app to let users explore a virtual kitchen, while estate agents offer virtual property tours. The healthcare sector uses VR as a teaching aid for surgeons and to treat phobias and post-traumatic stress disorder. In education, Google Expeditions provides virtual field trips for students, and other apps are being developed to teach language skills. A significant hurdle for VR's adoption, particularly in schools, is the cost of the necessary hardware and computing power.

The "black box" from a Russian Su-24 jet was opened in Moscow in front of journalists and diplomats. According to the head of the Russian investigation, Nikolai Primak, flight information appeared to be missing. Data from the box could resolve the dispute over the jet's location when it was shot down by Turkish F-16 fighters on November 24. Turkey claims the jet was in its airspace, while Russia says it was in Syrian airspace. The incident has led to a crisis between the two nations, with Russia imposing sanctions. The jet's pilot and a Russian marine involved in the rescue were killed, while the navigator was rescued. An analysis of the black box is expected to be released next week.

The Scottish women's football team has won all five of its qualifiers and faces a crucial match against Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. Both teams are unbeaten, and a victory for Scotland would almost secure their place in the finals. Player Lisa Evans states that failing to qualify again after previous near-misses would be "devastating" and "heartbreak." Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, is one of 12 players in the 20-strong squad who play for clubs outside of Scotland. She believes that having players in top foreign leagues benefits the national team by bringing a "different culture" and "a new way of playing."

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform found there is no "magic bullet" to fix the council tax system, which it says has had "built-in problems 'from day one'". The review, conducted by Prof Kenneth Gibb, examined different taxation systems. It found that a property tax is stable and difficult to avoid but is seen as unfair because it is not linked to income. A local income tax is perceived as fairer but creates fluctuating income for local authorities and offers little opportunity to vary rates. The commission, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, will hold a public consultation before reporting back in the autumn. The Scottish government considers the current system "unfair" and awaits the commission's report.

In response to the theft of celebrity photos from iCloud, Apple has extended its two-step verification system to cover iCloud backups. This security measure, which remains an opt-in choice, requires a user to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device when logging in from a new one. Without the code, access to iCloud and purchases from iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store is blocked. A 14-character recovery key can be used to regain access if a trusted device is lost. The creator of the software believed to have been used in the hacks confirmed that this change makes his tool unable to infiltrate the service. Experts suggest this feature should be the default setting, and Apple has stated it plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable it.

During the campaign period from 23 January to 22 May, the Conservatives spent the most at £2,980,815, while UKIP, which won the election, spent £2,956,737. Labour came second and spent £1,027,339, the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, and the Green Party spent £534,249. The cost per vote was £1.45 for the Lib Dems, 79p for the Conservatives, 68p for UKIP, 43p for the Green Party, and 26p for Labour. The six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087, and all but Labour spent more than in the 2009 campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals, the Gulls. He could play against his former club on 18 February. The Gulls have also brought in 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, whose move is subject to international clearance. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a "leader-type" and Keating as "young" and "hungry." The team is currently four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

The 10-year-old horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage" after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. According to the British Horseracing Authority (BHA), these episodes are rare and can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, which involved over-heating and wobbling, but had never collapsed before and did not show these symptoms on the day he died. A previous winner of the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, he was described by his trainer as the "horse of a lifetime".

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as several MSPs, including herself, Alex Salmond, and Duncan McNeil, are standing down before the 5 May election. In his farewell address, former first minister Mr. Salmond repeated his belief that Scotland was "diverse" not "divided" and concluded with the words, "goodbye from me... for now". Veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, who has served since 1999, used his final speech to warn that Holyrood needed to learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also bowing out of Holyrood.

The film, directed by Bill Condon, will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May and is scheduled for release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017. The cast includes Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and Josh Gad as LeFou. An unnamed star will play Mrs. Potts.

At 11:00 BST, the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision on whether to bring charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, where 96 football fans were fatally injured. The decision follows new inquests last year which concluded the fans were unlawfully killed, leading to evidence files on 23 suspects being sent to the CPS. Of these suspects, 15 are linked to the causes of the disaster, and eight are related to the subsequent police conduct investigation. Victims' relatives will be informed of the decision at a private meeting in Warrington. Margaret Aspinall, a relative of a victim, stated that the families want "accountability, nothing more and nothing less."

Chelmsford Prison has experienced "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over its wall. A former inmate stated the jail is "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A local resident witnessed packages being thrown over four times in two weeks, and the prison plans to hold a meeting with residents to discuss the issue. The Ministry of Justice said staff work "extremely hard" to stop contraband, but acknowledged "more must be done." The Justice Secretary is looking into providing prisons with better tools, and new laws mean smugglers can be jailed for up to two years. While a former inmate claimed drones were used, the Ministry of Justice said there was no evidence of this at the Chelmsford site.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving after striking Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, in Kempston. Mrs. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Mr. Wright denies the charge, telling Luton Crown Court that he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light, which his car failed to stop for. He expressed his remorse in court, and the trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner and veterinary medicine student, will not compete for Scotland at the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast. The event in April conflicts with her final year university exams in May. At the World Athletics Championships, Muir finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m, setting a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. She is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a "potentially a target" and believes she has "at least two, even three more Olympics" in her future.

Trevor Deely, 22, was last seen in December 2000 walking home from a Christmas party. A search, involving excavations, has begun at a three-acre site in Chapelizod, Dublin, and is expected to take several weeks. A review of the case led to enhanced CCTV footage showing Mr. Deely talking to an unidentified man in black outside his workplace. This same man is believed to have been captured on CCTV following Mr. Deely a short time later. Gardaí have renewed their appeal for this man to come forward.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165th after missing over two years due to injury, defeated the Swiss player Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3. Del Potro will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young.

In other matches:
*   Nick Kyrgios defeated Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 and will play Feliciano Lopez next.
*   Feliciano Lopez beat Fabio Fognini 3-6 6-7 6-3 6-3 6-3.
*   Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also secured victories.

Del Potro, Andy Murray, and Nick Kyrgios are all in the same half of the draw.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after complaining to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) about a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to Equatorial Guinea. Tunisia was required to apologize to avoid the ban, and its federation clarified it never accused Caf of corruption, but rather that the referee was "badly chosen." Meanwhile, Morocco was also able to enter the 2017 qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban imposed by Caf. Morocco had been punished for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, but Cas overturned the ban and reduced a $1m fine to $50,000.

The McLaren Formula 1 team, despite a history of 182 grand prix wins and numerous championships, has fallen from greatness and now has modest goals of a third or fourth-row grid position and some points. The team's current slump began in 2013 with chassis design issues, but now the problem lies with the Honda power-unit. The passage notes that McLaren's history is a cycle of triumph and decline, with previous dominant eras with Honda (notably winning 15 of 16 races in 1988) and Mercedes. The team has also experienced scandals, including being disqualified from the 2007 constructors' championship and the 'lie-gate' incident in 2009. Despite the current situation, team leader Ron Dennis and driver Fernando Alonso believe they will arrest the slide and return to winning championships. However, the text concludes that "right now, belief is all they have."

Following a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, an investigation found that alcohol was being served outside of licensing hours, with till receipts showing sales as late as 04:49 BST. The license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged. The judge ordered the bar to close for three months, fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000, and fined Mr. Thomas £1,000. The judge described Ms. O'Neill as having "an appalling record."

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry hit eight 3-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272. Klay Thompson added 26 points for the Warriors.

In another game, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78. The Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit, with Pau Gasol contributing 16 points and 15 rebounds. For the Heat, Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds.

YouTube star and Dutch free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen visited Melwood, where he met Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic. The players were under the impression that van Velzen was a competition winner there for a "dead-ball masterclass." However, it became clear he was not a regular fan when he showcased his own free-kick skills, surprising the players. Van Velzen called the experience "amazing" and said he enjoyed pretending he wasn't very good at free-kicks to see the players' reactions. He also had a final surprise for Balotelli, unveiling the forward's "infamous slogan."

A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with mutated BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes found that having an oophorectomy (ovary removal) can reduce the risk of death for carriers of the BRCA1 gene. For women with a BRCA1 mutation, the procedure was associated with a 62% drop in breast cancer death, but this benefit did not occur in those with a BRCA2 mutation. The study also found a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. For BRCA1 carriers who had their ovaries removed within two years of diagnosis, there was a 73% reduction in death. An editor for the journal JAMA Oncology stated the results were "compelling" and that oophorectomy should be part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancers.

On Easter Sunday morning in Durham, North Carolina, a married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train. The train, No. 80 the Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers were injured, and the train continued its route after a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes. According to a man who had met the couple, they may have lived in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member, is facing deportation after working as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years. He was promised US citizenship in exchange for his work, which helped in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. After retiring due to declining health, his temporary visa expired, and the DEA has refused to help with his citizenship. Toro fears he will be killed if he is sent back to Colombia. His former DEA handler, Mike McManus, believes Toro has "paid his dues" and deserves to stay in the United States.

The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the new ".sucks" domain to charge high sums to celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube and Bing. Kevin Spacey has reportedly paid to have his ".sucks" domain removed, with the recommended price for such domains being around $2,499 a year. ICANN has asked the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal.

Twenty-seven years after a baby boy's body was found in a village pond, his mother was arrested. The case was solved after police exhumed the body and a DNA sample led them to her. The woman explained that the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy from family and friends. The charge of infanticide was dropped after police ruled out foul play, but she remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby, originally buried by villagers, has been reburied and named Peter.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who was left with severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving car. The incident occurred five years ago when Mr. Young, mistakenly believing Mr. Hicks would not pay the fare, decided to drive him back to the taxi rank. Mr. Hicks jumped from the vehicle while it was travelling at over 20mph. A High Court judge ruled that the driver had unlawfully imprisoned his passenger. As a result of his injuries, Mr. Hicks developed epilepsy and now requires 24-hour care from his mother. The exact compensation amount is yet to be decided but is expected to be around 50 per cent of what the family requested, plus an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens were activated in Kansas due to storms, with a twister reported near Goddard and others in the southwestern part of the state near Aetna. According to a CNN expert, nighttime tornadoes are the most dangerous. The storms also impacted Missouri, where a possible tornado in Potosi resulted in reports of wind damage and flooding. Baseball-sized hail was reported in Farmington, Missouri. The weather service expects more storms on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to face each other in a middleweight fight in New Jersey on Saturday, with both fighters aiming for a title shot. Rockhold, who is seeking his fourth consecutive victory, plans to be "the bull" by coming forward to dominate Machida, whom he describes as a "matador." He believes he has seen weaknesses in Machida's style and has more ways to win. Machida is also confident, stating that he can win if he applies his own style and strategy. He feels well-prepared after an eight-week training camp and believes the winner of the fight deserves a title shot. Rockhold's last win was against Michael Bisping, and Machida's was against CB Dollaway.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft landed on its belly at the Aero Acres residential airpark without its landing gear deployed. The plane skidded along the runway, causing its propellers to hit the ground. The pilot then re-engaged the engines and took off again. The pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident, which is a type of "gear-up landing" most commonly caused by human error.

Manuel Pellegrini has admitted he is disappointed with Yaya Toure's performance this season, a sentiment he says Toure shares, but has vowed to support him until the end of the season. Manchester City will reportedly listen to offers for Toure as they look to overhaul their squad. Goalkeeper Joe Hart stated that the players have let the manager down and are disappointed in their own performances. The team will also be without captain Vincent Kompany, who could miss the rest of the campaign with a muscle injury. Additionally, Manchester City are interested in signing West Ham's Aaron Cresswell, but his manager, Sam Allardyce, has warned him about the potential risks of such a move.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive who has lived in the UK for over 20 years, will be allowed to remain in the country after his seven-year prison sentence from Italy was dropped. Rancadore was convicted in absentia in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. Although he lost an extradition battle, his sentence expired in October of the previous year under an Italian law that extinguishes a sentence once a period more than double the penalty has passed. Consequently, the European Arrest Warrant against him is being withdrawn. The case still needs to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court.

AP McCoy will ride Mr Mole in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, which will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. Mr Mole is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the seven-runner race. It was after riding Mr Mole to victory in February that McCoy announced his intention to quit riding. His final book of rides as a professional jockey will be finalised on Friday morning.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of a girl named Marcia who was murdered 40 years ago, recently saw crime scene photos of her daughter's body for the first time, an experience she described as horrifying. Marcia was raped and choked to death in 1975 by Jerome Sydney Barrett, and her body was found 33 days after she disappeared. After viewing the photos, Ritter expressed a desire for revenge. The murder was unsolved for 33 years until Barrett was identified through DNA evidence and arrested in 2006. In 2009, he was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years.

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, which would make him the sixth player to win all four major titles. He considers his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta the "most important day of his career," as he learned a great deal from it, which helped him win his first major two months later. McIlroy, who has one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, hopes to win multiple green jackets and uses the golf course as a "sanctuary" from pressure and hype.

Based on the passage, this week's trending stories included:
*   Four rainbows appearing over the New York area, photographed by Amanda Curtis.
*   A crackdown in rural China on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes.
*   RDJ becoming agitated when a UK interviewer asked about his private life.
*   A new trend, the #kyliejennerchallenge, involving lip plumping by sucking on a jar to look like Kylie Jenner.
*   102-year-old Alice Barker going "back in time" with the help of filmmakers.
*   A school disallowing a "prom-posal" that referenced bombs, leading to the student accusing administrators of racism.
*   Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'.
*   Johnny Depp appearing nearly unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer.
*   A pregnancy announcement that referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."
*   A military dad photobombing his son.

According to figures from the official health and social care information centre, 272 children were hospitalised in England last year due to foetal alcohol syndrome, though experts warn the actual number could be much higher. Research by the World Health Organisation suggests that one in 100 babies in the UK, or about 7,500 a year, could suffer from learning, behavioural, and physical problems from alcohol exposure. Elizabeth Mitchell of the national organisation for foetal alchol syndrome states that the condition is permanent and "vastly under-diagnosed." Other associated medical issues include problems with the liver, kidneys, and heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. While the government advises pregnant women not to drink, or to limit consumption to two units no more than twice a week, Ms. Mitchell believes the guidance should be changed to advise against drinking any alcohol during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, an axe-wielding robber, was jailed for six years after his attempt to rob the Shildon Post Office and Stores was foiled. The shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, rugby-tackled the 31-year-old, and as they wrestled, Dhillon's wife, Sam, hit McKerry with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him. McKerry, who pleaded guilty to attempted robbery, was known as "boomerang boy" or "homing pigeon boy" in his youth because he always returned home after committing crimes. He had been arrested 80 times by the age of 15.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a Canadian barracks in Nova Scotia. The men, Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35), were in Canada for a Royal Navy ice hockey tournament. They have been granted bail under the conditions that they surrender their passports, remain in Nova Scotia, and live at the Stadacona naval base until their trial. As part of a deal with the British government, they will continue to be employed and paid by the Royal Navy. The charges of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault are punishable by up to 14 years in prison.

A four-year-old boy named RJ Jackson has Netherton's syndrome, an incredibly rare disease that makes his skin appear red, scaly, and as if it has been scalded. His mother, Valerie Jackson, was reported to the police for child abuse by a stranger who mistook her son's condition for burns. While shopping, she was surrounded by armed police, to whom she had to explain the situation. The family also faces taunts from the public and has been denied entry to a playhouse due to RJ's appearance. Valerie manages his painful symptoms by regularly covering him in creams.

A Protein World advert on the London Underground, featuring a bikini-clad model with the slogan "are you beach body ready?", sparked a major controversy. The campaign was criticized by feminists and body image campaigners, leading to a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures, more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA), and defaced posters. Transport for London (TfL) confirmed the posters were being removed because the three-week advertising period the company had paid for had ended. Protein World defended the campaign, with its head of marketing calling it "fantastic" and revealing the company had received a bomb threat.

Rail firms are planning fare increases of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite pledges from the main political parties to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has asked First Great Western (FGW) to "urgently review" its decision to increase some fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which affects his constituency. This specific hike would see an off-peak return ticket rise from £33.30 to £62.40 for passengers returning during the evening peak. These increases are on "unregulated" fares. Other companies, including London Midlands and Virgin, are also introducing price hikes, though Virgin states its overall increase is below the industry average.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, has been blinded in his left eye after being hit by a brick thrown by thugs at his home in Oldham. The incident occurred when Mr. Young confronted the attackers for throwing stones at his property. When he opened his front door, another brick was thrown, striking him. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his sight. The attack, which police believe may have no motive, happened just three weeks after Mr. Young and his wife, Elaine, were married.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a new one-year contract extension, committing him to the county until the end of the 2016 season. This follows his successful return from leg injuries sustained in a road accident in April 2014, in which his father died. The injury, which required an ankle operation, caused him to miss the entire 2014 campaign. He made his playing comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, has been given the all-clear by doctors. To help him feel stronger and brave during his radiotherapy, he decorated the protective mask that held him still to look like a Ninja Turtle. After undergoing treatments including chemotherapy, surgery, and a stem cell transplant, he is now cancer-free. His story gained attention, leading to him receiving presents from the TV channel Nickelodeon and becoming the face of Cancer Research UK's Kids & Teens campaign.

According to his manager Tim Sherwood, 19-year-old Jack Grealish must concentrate on his Aston Villa career before deciding on his international future. Grealish, who starred in the FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, is at the centre of a "tug of war" between the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood believes that if Grealish focuses on establishing himself at Villa, the international options will be his to choose from, and he should then "go with your heart." Grealish's father, Kevin, agrees with this advice. Grealish has played for Ireland's youth teams and is expected to make his decision at the end of the season.

Landing fees for private jets can vary dramatically, revealing some unexpectedly popular transport hubs for the wealthy. Private jet travel is a growing, multi-trillion dollar industry in the US and Europe, with the busiest and most expensive times to fly occurring during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix. According to a list compiled by the website The Richest, based on a 767-400 aircraft, the three most expensive airports for landing fees are all in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most expensive at £4,559. Other airports in the top ten include Toronto, Darwin, Bristol, Dublin, La Guardia (the only US airport on the list), and Salzburg.

A video of two dogs, Cooper and Daisy, getting an ice cream from a McDonald's drive-thru has been watched more than seven million times. The video shows Daisy taking a few licks while Cooper, a Labrador, eats the rest of the cone in one bite. Their owner, Katie Gallegos, says Cooper always eats quickly, so she makes sure Daisy gets her share first. In response to criticism for feeding her dogs the treat, Gallegos stated that Cooper is in "amazing health" and that her previous dog, who lived to be 19, also had ice cream weekly. Another video shows the dogs getting a "pup-uccino," which is just whipped cream, from Starbucks.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock, signing a three-year contract. He initially joined the club as an assistant boss and took over as interim manager at the start of February. Since taking charge, he has lost just one of his seven games.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, accused a school of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, because of the doTERRA essential oils he wears. Kemp applies the oils, which have scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, to her son's head and neck to keep him calm and focused. Teachers at Seminole County Elementary warned that the oils' smell was a distraction, and the school board sent a letter stating they had created a "problem" for staff and students. Although Kemp planned to fight the decision, the Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue."

On Wednesday at 3 pm, a fire destroyed a 90-unit beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, causing the building to collapse. The blaze was so intense that smoke was visible from three miles away and it melted the paint on nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews responded but were unable to get inside the building. The cause of the fire is unknown, but an investigation is underway, including claims it may have started near a car. The Sandpiper complex is used as a holiday home between May and November, and the building manager who lived and worked there lost everything.

At 88 years old, the Queen was seen riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She does not wear a helmet, opting for a silk scarf instead, reportedly due to her hair. A lifelong rider since the age of four, she has reduced her time in the saddle in recent years because of a knee injury. The Queen breeds several types of horses, including Fell ponies at Hampton Court and Highland ponies at Balmoral. The passage also describes Fell ponies as an ancient, hardy breed from Cumbria that were historically used as pack and work animals before becoming popular for riding in the 1950s.

An argument over noise between two Brisbane neighbours ended with one man, 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, dead and another, 28-year-old Phillip Pama, charged with manslaughter. The incident occurred on a Thursday night when Mr. Yeaman was reportedly making a lot of noise while Pama, a shift worker, was sleeping. Pama confronted Mr. Yeaman, allegedly killing him with a single punch. Pama has been granted conditional bail, which requires him to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and report to police twice a week. The case is due to return to court on May 18.
DID NOT RECIEVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

Chelsea football manager José Mourinho prays to God every day but never about football, and he does not discuss the game with his wife. The 52-year-old father-of-two, who has worked with the World Food Programme as an ambassador against hunger, tries to separate his professional and family life. He goes to church when he feels the need and always does so when in Portugal. Despite his professional persona, Mourinho believes he is a good person, a good family man, and a good friend.

For the first time in eight years, Bob Barker returned to "The Price is Right" on the April 1 edition. Barker, who is 91 and hosted the show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, handled the first game of the show, "Lucky Seven," before turning hosting duties over to Drew Carey.

An off-duty Secret Service agent named Arthur Baldwin was arrested at 12:30 am on Friday in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. As a result of the arrest, the Secret Service revoked his security clearance and put him on leave. Baldwin was assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch. His arrest is noted as one of several recent incidents of misconduct for the agency.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, got out of his car at a safari park in Lahore to photograph a male lion. He crept to within 10 feet of the animal, armed only with a camera. The clicking of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, which jumped aggressively towards him, forcing Mr. Saeed to retreat rapidly to his car. He stated he was trying to capture the "character and status of lion" and later reflected that he would not be able to do it again.

New York City police are seeking to identify a woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, who was found dead in Brooklyn on March 22. To aid in her identification, they have released an image of a distinctive tattoo on her right leg, which features a heart topped with a rose and a ribbon with the name 'Monique'. The woman had no identification on her, and the cause of death is pending a medical examiner's report. Police are asking anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

After returning to New Zealand from the UK, a couple named Hannah and Alex built a home on a 1986 Hino flatbed truck because they could not afford to buy property. The project took a year and a half and cost about $25,000. The result is a solar-powered, two-bedroom home made of wood and steel, which also has a wood-fired stove. The couple now lives almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand, with water coming from a nearby spring and their first power bill being just $25.

According to research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, kindergarten children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests. The study of 352 students found that those who shared iPads scored about 30 points higher than students who had their own device or no iPad at all. Blackwell suggests that the "collaborative learning around the technology" is what made the difference and that schools should reconsider how tablets are used in early grades to be most effective.

A piglet born without its back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front two trotters. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," belongs to a farmer named Ms. Duan in Qionglai city, China. A heartwarming video of the animal walking and foraging for food has captured the hearts of thousands online, and villagers have flocked to see it. The piglet happily mixes with its siblings, all of whom were born with four legs.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday, pit crew member Todd Phillips was struck and injured by the car of Francesco Dracone. The incident occurred on lap 25 when Dracone's car spun while exiting the pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center, where he received stitches for a cut on his leg and was then released. Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd.

CCTV footage captured Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, smashing his 29-year-old dancer wife's head into concrete paving 11 times and then shooting her in the face five times. Severiano confessed that he carried out the act because he was "jealous of men looking at her." The victim, Cicera Alves de Sena, belonged to a dance group called Jaula das gostozuedas. The incident occurred just four days after the couple was married. After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was arrested after crashing it. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car, and he now faces life in jail.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, 41, has revealed her personal battle with mental illness, which brought her to a point where she considered taking her own life. She explained that a combination of mounting stress, anxiety, her thyroid disease, and feeling isolated and alone due to a distant family and not having a husband or children, drove her to believe her life was no longer worth living. Wilson now accepts she is an "anxious person" and has "found some peace with it." She believes that depression and anxiety are "intrinsically linked" and that anxiety is becoming the "new depression."

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, will no longer face prosecution for second-degree assault. The charge was filed in November 2014 after she came home, found her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom, and struck her with a crowbar when the woman refused to leave. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." According to the text, Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who will not leave a resident's home. If convicted, Curtin would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was being fed treats when her owner threw a broccoli spear into the mix as a trick. The dog pulled a look of disgust, chomped on the vegetable, and then spit it out on the floor. Gemma lives with two children, and other videos show her sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was for the bank's "young entrepreneur awards," which were discontinued in 2011. After the awards were scrapped, the organizers allowed the registration for the associated URL on hsbc.com.hk to expire, and a porn site took over the address. HSBC has since removed the hyperlink, denied any association with the external site, and issued a public apology, insisting its website remained secure.

On a Sunday morning in Clinton, Maryland, a 13-year-old boy named Marcus called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his home, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, in a second-floor bedroom. During the 11-minute call, Marcus remained calm, provided instructions to firefighters, and soothed his sister. Firefighters entered the room, broke a window, and rescued both children. A firefighter gave his gas mask to the girl. The siblings were taken to a children's hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, and three other family members who escaped on their own were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae has been photographed lighting up Australia's east coast in Jervis Bay, NSW. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight, caused by millions of light-omitting plankton, as a "beautiful supernatural scene." According to Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales, the glow is caused by *Noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in the spring and autumn. The glow is a defense mechanism for the cell. A similar display was seen in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.

New genetic tests can analyse a breast cancer patient's tumour to determine its aggressiveness and the risk of the cancer returning. One such test, EndoPredict, can identify women with a low risk of recurrence (as low as five per cent), allowing them to be spared chemotherapy and its difficult side effects. Currently, most women are routinely given chemotherapy after surgery. These new tests are mostly available privately at a cost of about £2,500, but specialists believe making them available on the NHS could be cost-effective by saving money on chemotherapy treatments and allowing patients to make a more informed choice.

Based on the text provided, more than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with one ship, HMS Ocean, having five such medevacs in nine years. Additionally, 99 servicewomen were flown back from Afghanistan (2006-2013) and 102 were evacuated from Iraq for the same reason. A strict "no touching" rule is in place on ships, and military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones. Troops are reminded to check for pregnancy before deployment but are not required to take tests.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium, a small camera, and smoke flares was found on the rooftop of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence. The amount of the radioactive material was not immediately harmful to humans. The discovery has raised concerns about potential terrorism involving drones, prompting the government to consider reviewing regulations for unmanned vehicles, as there are currently no flight restrictions over most of Tokyo, including the Prime Minister's residence. The discovery occurred on the same day a court approved a plan to restart two nuclear reactors.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who has Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on his motorbike. He is afraid she will get lost if left alone, as she has wandered off before. After his father passed away, he became her primary caregiver. To keep her safe on the four-kilometre journey, he ties a sash around both of their waists. His employer, a bank, has provided a room for his mother at his workplace, where he can check on her. Mr. Lu feels it is his duty to care for his mother in return for the care she gave him as a child.

According to a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, heavy drinking and binge-drinking among Americans increased between 2005 and 2012. Heavy drinking rose by 17.2%, an increase largely driven by women's drinking habits. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. The study defines heavy drinking as more than one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking is four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion. Potential reasons for the increase include changing social norms for women, the relative cheapness of alcohol, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies.

UN officials from the World Health Organisation (WHO) warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, which puts the health of women and their babies at risk. They state the procedure should only be performed when "medically necessary" and that the ideal rate is between 10 and 15 per cent. In England, the rate is just over a quarter and has more than doubled since the early 1990s. This is partly because NHS guidelines allow women to have the operation for anxiety about childbirth, which contradicts the WHO's advice. The WHO notes that caesareans can lead to complications, disability, or death and are more costly to the NHS than a natural birth.

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owner's property in a yard sale. The owner, Mark Conklin, discovered her in the home on April 17. Filkins has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.
MODEL FAILED TO RETURN ANY OUTPUT

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was mauled to death in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa after it was caught in a fight between two adult hippos. The calf's mother watched as one of the adults grabbed the baby in its jaws, threw it into the air, and dragged it along the surface of the water. The baby hippo died from its injuries hours later.

A three-bedroom, "unmodernised" apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is for sale for £575,000. The property's low price is because it only has three years remaining on its lease and requires renovation. The cost is comparable to renting in the area at £15,000 per month. If a buyer extends the lease, which is estimated to cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. It is one of two maisonettes being sold with a three-year lease, and despite warnings about the high cost of extending the lease, there has been significant interest.

A computer outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, affected 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada on a Friday night. The glitch disrupted sales registers, which led to baristas giving away free drinks and some locations closing early. The issue was resolved late Friday night, with stores expected to open for "business as usual" on Saturday. This outage occurred one day after Starbucks had reported record quarterly earnings.

According to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, terrorists are undergoing training and radicalizing Muslims in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. He stated that those involved participate in "seemingly ordinary activities" but have an "ulterior motive." The article provides historical examples of extremist activity in Wales, including a group sent by Abu Hamza to train in the Brecon Beacons in 1998, two of the 7/7 bombers being photographed in North Wales in 2005, and Michael Adebowale, one of Lee Rigby's murderers, having studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead. DC Jones emphasized that community intelligence is vital to the authorities.

An Omura's whale, a species once feared to be extinct, washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in West Australia after tropical cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and the second in Australia. The 5.68m juvenile female was identified using DNA profiling. The discovery is considered "highly significant" for scientists as very little is known about the species, which was first described in 2003 and is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale's skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and possible public display.

The passage discusses the argument made by a Texas businesswoman, Cheryl Rios, that Hillary Clinton's hormones make her unfit for the presidency. The author refutes this by suggesting male hormones have historically impaired male leaders' decision-making and that studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. The author argues that the debate over hormones is a distraction from the real issue: a pervasive gender bias against women in the workplace and leadership. Evidence of this bias includes the fact that there are more men on corporate boards named John, Robert, William, or James than there are women on boards altogether. The passage concludes that gender equality benefits everyone and points out the irony of Rios threatening to move to Canada, a country that had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is selling his collection of over 200 antiques in a £100,000 auction as he is downsizing his home. The sale, held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers, includes items reflecting his interest in military history and the medieval longbow, such as a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a portrait of him holding a longbow, furniture, books, and swords. Hardy is known for his roles in *All Creatures Great and Small*, as Winston Churchill, and as Cornelius Fudge in the *Harry Potter* films.

Michael Scott Shemansky is on the run from police after being named a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky. He became a suspect after he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead in the Winter Garden home they shared. Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was going through a divorce. Neighbors believe the stress of the divorce and receiving "bad news" paperwork may have "triggered him." He was last seen fleeing on foot without any provisions or medication. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council bypassed the usual bidding process, calling it a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid for the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, an aspiring model, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. She targeted Hassan after seeing him with a large amount of cash at a casino, befriended him, and went back to his flat. There, she left the door unlocked for her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler. The two men tied up Hassan, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and jailed for life with a minimum term of 36 years. All three defendants were also convicted of robbing Mr. Hassan and conspiracy to falsely imprison him.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas is experiencing a slump in form during the second half of the season, a trend that was also noted by his former club, Barcelona. After a strong start with 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, his contributions have decreased, and he has only managed one assist in the last five games he has played. This dip in performance, attributed to fatigue from playing nearly every match, was highlighted by his poor showing in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland. Despite this, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho hopes for a late-season resurgence from Fabregas to help secure the Premier League title.

West Ham are discussing a deal for 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford after he impressed on a two-week trial with the club's academy. Beckford, who has offers from clubs in Belgium, is considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean. Meanwhile, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the 54,000-capacity Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289 for the 2016-17 season, which will be the cheapest in the Premier League.

Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, three months after it took place. Mr. Lane was beaten by protesters, kicked in the head, and suffered concussion and broken teeth. He called the police decision "pathetic," stating that a wealth of evidence was provided, including a video of the incident, a photograph of the main suspect, names of saboteurs, and their car registration numbers. Wiltshire Police confirmed they stopped the investigation due to "insufficient evidence" and have recorded the case as "undetected," but will re-open it if new evidence comes to light.

Adam Gadahn, known as the American mouthpiece for al Qaeda, was killed at age 36 in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. According to the White House, he was not specifically targeted. In what was likely a separate operation, another American al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, was killed, along with two hostages, Warren Weinstein and Giovanni Lo Porto.

Originally from California, Gadahn converted to Islam and moved to Pakistan in 1998. He became al Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist, appearing in numerous videos threatening attacks, criticizing U.S. presidents, and urging lone-wolf attacks in America. In 2006, he was indicted for treason and was on the FBI's "most wanted terrorists" list.

A five-year-old boy in China named Mai Zizhuo has become a new basketball superstar after a viral video showed him displaying a dazzling array of basketball skills. Mai Zizhuo, who has been playing since he was two and a half, is seen in the video scoring a succession of hoops and dribbling two basketballs at once. His skills have won him legions of fans across China, and netizens have left thousands of comments praising his potential.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. He attended a Hacked Off rally, chaired by John Cleese, in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. PIE campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals." A Hacked Off spokesman stated that the meeting was open to all members of the public.

On a Thursday, the Bondi Icebergs club pool was drained to serve as a catwalk for the "ten pieces" presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, forcing lap swimmers to go to the beach. Headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, the brand presented a unisex, monochrome capsule collection of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall in front of an ocean backdrop as guests and passers-by watched.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan went on a family trip with his wife and daughter to a safari park in northern California, where he fed a white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions. Khan also announced that his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation that he would fight British rival Kell Brook.

The name of a Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, will be removed from an Israeli memorial for fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism after his family and an organization called Almagor complained. Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis, had his name added to the memorial wall at Mount Herzl. His father objected, stating he refused to have his son's name listed with "soldiers of the occupation." Almagor also opposed the inclusion, describing the teen's death as a "rogue attack" and not an act of terrorism. In response to the complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the site, will remove the name from the memorial wall and has already removed it from the memorial's website.

A California-based YouTube user named Lionel Hutz filmed his young son in a garden as the boy repeatedly tried to use the family cat as a pillow. Each time the boy lay on the cat, the cat would get up and move to a new spot, with the boy following. This happened multiple times before the cat went indoors. A later video showed the two had made up, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past as a marijuana dealer. Kushner, one of over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the government, alleged that officers on trial had stolen $81,000 and marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. The school was unaware of his history, as the 2007 charges had been expunged. Kushner was also arrested in 2011, sentenced to four years of probation, and pleaded guilty to a DUI in 2008. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China, sparked a large fire and injured six people. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a chemical described as controversial and reportedly carcinogenic. The blast, which occurred on a Monday night, was caused by an oil leak at a storage facility. Five of the injured were hurt by broken glass. More than 600 firefighters were sent to the scene, and the fire is now under control. This same plant experienced another explosion in July 2013 and was relocated to its current location from Xiamen in 2007 following protests over pollution concerns.

Aston Villa's Jack Grealish has stated that he will not listen to Premier League referees who tell him to pull up his socks. He wears his stockings low, just above his shinpads, due to a lifelong superstition. Grealish also revealed that he wears children's size shinpads. This was discussed after he made his first Premier League start for the club in a 3-3 draw against QPR, a start he was pleased to make.

According to her grandmother Cissy Houston, Bobbi Kristina Brown has "global and irreversible brain damage" and is unresponsive, though she is no longer in a medically induced coma. Her father, Bobby Brown, stated that his daughter was "awake" and "watching me," but a family attorney clarified that he was in an "emotional state" when he made those remarks. The attorney also stated that Bobbi Kristina is starting a rehabilitation process and that while doctors indicate she will have a long life, the quality of her life will not be known for years.

Russia holds a 2-0 lead over Germany in the Fed Cup. Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets, and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova beat Sabine Lisicki after saving a match point. As a result, Russia needs only one win from the three matches on Sunday to reach the final.

Residents of New South Wales, who were recently hit by wild weather, are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage from another storm predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists say an east coast low could bring heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday, with the main impacts expected on coastal areas in the state's northeast. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that the new storm will hamper clean-up efforts, as they still have over 4,000 jobs to complete from the last storm. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region, as more rain on already saturated ground could raise flood levels again.

Model Nina Moric, who appeared in a Ricky Martin video, was hospitalized after what Italian media and her boyfriend reported as a suicide attempt. Moric denied these claims on her Instagram, stating she collapsed and was injured due to low blood pressure. She posted photos of her bruises and told followers she was recovering at home. The passage also mentions that Italian media had previously claimed she attempted suicide in 2009 and that she was once married to paparazzi Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son.

According to a YouGov poll for the Sunday Times, the British public's favorite name for Kate and William's second child, if it is a girl, is Diana, with 12% of the vote. Alice and Charlotte were the next most popular choices, each with 9%. For a boy, the preferred name is James, with 13% of the vote, followed by Alexander. Of the 2,200 people polled, a quarter wanted the couple to have a girl, while only 3% hoped for a boy. The poll also found that 68% of people support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

On Thursday in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, a suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters, killing 17 people and wounding 64. An Afghan lawmaker, Humayoon Humayoon, was among the wounded. The protesters were on their way to a rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban has denied responsibility for the attack, and no other group has claimed it.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after his representative, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that he had rejected the club's final contract offer. The offer was for a three-year extension, but it was dependent on Alves playing in 60 per cent of the club's matches. Santana stated that "the negotiations are over."

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has urged his former teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games for Boca, believes the duo would be a "perfect" fit for the team due to their "South-American style" and that the fans at La Bombonera would "go absolutely crazy" for them.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson had a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton, which has become an internet sensation. He only sustained a cut on his nose from the ordeal. The following day, he was back at Paul Nicholls's yard mucking out stables and riding out, and he remains undeterred from getting back in the saddle. Ferguson described the fall as a "blur" and joked about a potential gymnastics career.

To coincide with the release of the movie *Avengers: Age of Ultron*, London Wasps captain and England flanker James Haskell posted a photo on Instagram of himself dressed as Iron Man. Haskell first joined the Wasps in 2002, leaving in 2009 to play in France, Japan, and New Zealand. He returned to the Wasps in 2012 and has since surpassed 100 appearances for the club, earning 57 caps for England to-date.

The wide-leg trouser is a key trend for SS15, offering an effortless alternative to the skinny jean. To wear the style, it is recommended to pair them with high heels to elongate the leg and a simple top like a knit, shirt, or tee to keep the outfit in proportion. For longer styles, a high-waisted and very long cut is suggested. Denim is cited as the easiest way to adopt the trend, with examples from Gucci and Topshop. Dressier versions have been showcased by Celine and Stella McCartney.

The University of Michigan will proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" after initially canceling it. The cancellation followed a petition from over 200 students who felt the movie's depiction of the Iraq War reflected negatively on people from the Middle East. After a backlash and a counter-petition, the university's vice president for student life, E. Royster Harper, announced the reversal, stating the initial cancellation was a "mistake" and inconsistent with the university's value of freedom of expression. An alternative film, "Paddington," will be offered for those who do not wish to see "American Sniper."

On April 3rd on Rottnest Island, two French male tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly used an ignited aerosol spray to set a quokka on fire. The animal survived but was singed. Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, and evicted them from the island. Both men have been charged with animal cruelty and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

At 102 years old, former dancer Alice Barker was shown videos of herself dancing for the first time. Barker danced in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club in the 1930s and 1940s alongside notables such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Having lost all her photographs and memorabilia, she had never seen the motion pictures made of her. Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and some volunteers showed her a video of "soundies," or early music videos, at her nursing home, and she was delighted.

Based on a survey of 1,100 adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV, the practice of washing one's own car is declining in Britain. The study found that a third of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own car, with drivers now more likely to use a car wash. Reasons for this shift include shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and vehicles like 4x4s being too large to clean. Additionally, only five percent of those surveyed had ever asked their children to wash the car for pocket money.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard, whom he considers one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool. Skrtel stated that Gerrard helped him settle at the club when he arrived in 2008. Gerrard is set to leave Liverpool for LA Galaxy, with a potential final game in the FA Cup final on his birthday, May 30. While Skrtel acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without him, he believes the club has players who can replace Gerrard with the help of the team.

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National. It was his first ace at Augusta and was one of five holes-in-one that day, which tied a record from 2002. Camilo Villegas also had two aces but lost the contest to Kevin Streelman in a play-off. The passage also notes that Nicklaus became the youngest person to wear a green jacket in 1963, won his sixth in 1986, and is one of five men to have completed the career grand slam.

On Wednesday night, tornado sirens were activated in Kansas due to storms, with a twister reported near Goddard and other sightings near Aetna. The storms also affected Missouri, where a possible tornado in Potosi resulted in reports of wind damage and flooding. In Farmington, Missouri, there was baseball-sized hail. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers stated that nighttime tornadoes are the most dangerous. The weather service predicted more storms for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris. Bates claims he meant to use a Taser but mistakenly shot Harris with a gun. A judge granted Bates permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, a decision that the victim's family said "sends a message of apathy." The lawyer for Harris's family claims Bates was unqualified and received preferential treatment for making donations to the agency. The Tulsa County Sheriff's office denies allegations reported by the *Tulsa World* newspaper that supervisors were told to forge Bates' records. One of Bates' lawyers released training documents said to prove he was properly trained. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo in Las Vegas on July 11. Ahead of the fight, McGregor has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach, which adds to an existing tattoo of a gorilla on his chest. This will be Aldo's eighth defence of his belt, and McGregor claims he has greater motivation to win than Aldo. The two have a fractious relationship, which was demonstrated when McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer at an Australian rules function, which drew cheers from players but criticism from anti-drinking campaigners. A cultural studies professor, Julie Robert, called the act "problematic," stating that it glorified binge drinking and associated masculinity with heavy alcohol consumption. In his defense, Health Minister Sussan Ley said there was "nothing wrong" with his actions and pointed to his healthy lifestyle. Opposition Leader Bill Shorten quipped that he was "pleased that tony abbott’s learning to drink beer without adding lemonade to it." The passage also notes that while former Prime Minister Bob Hawke was known for skolling, attitudes towards binge drinking have since changed.

Indiana is experiencing a significant HIV outbreak in Scott County, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to intravenous drug users. In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a temporary 30-day needle exchange program. More than two weeks in, the program has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants. The governor is now considering whether to extend the program, which he opposes as an anti-drug policy. The future of the program and of legislation that would allow other counties to establish similar exchanges is uncertain, partly due to concerns that such programs promote drug use and a lack of public funding.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a test about his favorite football club. The test was formatted like a school exam with multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and "in your own words" sections. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50 (87%), and her boyfriend commented that as a result, he would not be dumping her. She posted pictures of the test on her Twitter account, which led to mixed reactions from other users. Some called the boyfriend a "legend" and were impressed with Saskia's knowledge, while others felt he had taken things too far, calling him a "biff-head."

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel, is facing deportation after working for 27 years as an undercover informant for the DEA. He worked in exchange for a promise of US citizenship, which he has not received. After retiring due to declining health, his temporary visa expired, leaving him in the US illegally. Toro's work as an informant helped in the prosecution of figures like cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. He fears he will be killed if he is deported to Colombia.

A 14-year-old girl in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. She is now in a Delhi hospital with 70 percent burns, and the accused men have been arrested. This event is contextualized by a heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, highlighted by the recent ban of the documentary "India's Daughter," which covers the gang rape and murder of student Jyoti Singh. The passage also mentions incidents of vigilante justice in Nagaland, where mobs have beaten men accused of rape to death.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is dreaming of beating Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford. He has ruled out both Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw for the match, stating that neither is fit enough to play. Van Gaal believes a win would be a "big step up the table," making third place available and almost certainly qualifying the team for the top four. He played down the idea of revenge for a previous loss to City, instead emphasizing the need to "control your aggression." This will be his first Manchester derby at Old Trafford.

A section of Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Barclays Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest, which included banners inside and outside the ground, came after the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal. The cheapest tickets for the game were £64, prompting a banner that read, "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket". The protest was a united effort organised by fan groups from both clubs, and further protests were expected after the match.

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with a life-threatening liver condition called biliary atresia. After an initial operation to unblock her bile ducts was unsuccessful, her parents were told she would need a liver transplant to survive. As neither parent was a suitable match, the baby's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader (her mother's twin sister), donated part of her liver. The transplant operation was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery, though she will require lifelong anti-rejection medication and weekly tests.

Chelsea football players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in an Audi football challenge, pairing up as Hazard and Ake versus Remy and Willian. The challenges included firing footballs into the boot of a car, playing over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 plus as a net, and shooting into a convertible Audi from long range. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, but Remy and Willian won the final challenge. During the event, Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror of one of the Audis with a long-range shot.

Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, her 29-year-old fiancé Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100mph, hitting their SUV. During his sentencing, Dellinger stated he was not suicidal, contradicting what prosecutors said he had previously told investigators. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault and faces 12 to 24 years in prison, as well as a wrongful death lawsuit. Dellinger's attorneys claimed he was suffering from multiple sclerosis and the effects of several medications.

Lacey Spears was convicted of killing her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt and was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. Spears, who prosecutors said made her son ill for attention, appeared emotionless at the sentencing. The boy's father, Chris Hill, reacted with anger on Facebook. The judge stated that Spears suffers from a mental illness and called the crime "unfathomable in its cruelty." Spears' lawyer maintained her innocence, blamed the hospital for negligence, and planned to appeal the verdict.

An improved influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia a month later than expected. The delay is due to scientists adding protection against two new strains, influenza A (H3N2) and influenza B (B/Phuket), which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States. The vaccine, which also protects against H1N1, is considered by experts to be worth the wait. From April 20, free, government-funded flu shots will be available to high-risk groups, such as the very young, the very old, and most Indigenous Australians. Dr. Alan Hampson of the Influenza Specialist Group advises that everyone should get the vaccine and book their shots now due to the delay.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing two main challenges: an unflattering critique in *National Geographic* magazine and potential budget cuts. The magazine article described the tomb as a "disappointment" with "all the historical character of an office lobby." Simultaneously, due to a state financial crisis, Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the site. These issues are occurring around the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination.
